choices.text: Extend knee and plantar flex foot
Flex knee and plantar flex foot

questions.text: A pregnant woman has cramps in her legs. What will you suggest her to relieve the pain?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Extend knee and dorsiflex foot

 

Extension at the knee joint and dorsiflexion at the ankle joint helps in stretching the calf muscles, which relieves the pain.

 

Leg cramps are common during pregnancy, often due to a deficiency of diffusible serum calcium or an elevation of serum phosphorus. Management includes:

 

  • Massaging the leg
  • Stretching exercises
  • Application of local heat
  • Supplementation of vitamin B1 and calcium

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Flex knee and dorsiflex foot: Incorrect. This position does not adequately stretch the calf muscles and may not relieve the cramp.

 

Option C. Extend knee and plantar flex foot: Incorrect. Plantar flexion can worsen the cramp by further contracting the calf muscles.

 

Option D. Flex knee and plantar flex foot: Incorrect. This position does not stretch the calf muscles and may exacerbate the pain.

 

Educational Objective:


To relieve leg cramps, suggest extension of the knee and dorsiflexion of the foot to effectively stretch the calf muscles. Additionally, consider correcting any nutritional deficiencies associated with leg cramps in pregnancy.

choices.text: Head rotated by 1/8th of a circle
Head rotating due to untwisting of the neck
The shoulder undergoing rotation by 1/8th of circle
The movement by which the head is born

questions.text: What is restitution? (INICET NOV 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Head rotating due to untwisting of the neck

 

Restitution is one of the cardinal movements of labor that occurs after the delivery of the fetal head. During internal rotation, the fetal neck gets twisted by 45 degrees (for example, in Left Occipital Anterior position). Once the head is delivered and free from the bony confines of the pelvis, it naturally untwists to align with the fetal body. This untwisting movement of the head is called restitution.

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Head rotated by 1/8th of a circle: Incorrect. Restitution isn't defined by the degree of rotation (though a 45-degree rotation is approximately 1/8th of a circle). Rather, restitution specifically refers to the untwisting mechanism and its purpose.

 

Option C. The shoulder undergoing rotation by 1/8th of circle: Incorrect. Shoulder rotation occurs after restitution and is part of a different cardinal step called external rotation. During external rotation, the shoulders enter the pelvis and undergo internal rotation, which manifests as the head rotating externally.

 

Option D. The movement by which the head is born: Incorrect. This describes extension, which is the movement that occurs when the head is being delivered, before restitution takes place.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Restitution is the untwisting movement of the fetal head that occurs after delivery of the head, correcting the twist that occurred during internal rotation.

questions.text: Identify the site which is responsible for relieving pain when pressure is applied to the painful area? (AIIMS Nov 2018)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Periaqueductal gray

 

The analgesia system consists of three major components:

 

(1) The periaqueductal gray and periventricular areas of the mesencephalon and upper pons surround the aqueduct of Sylvius and portions of the third and fourth ventricles. Neurons from these areas send signals to  

 

(2) the raphe magnus nucleus, a thin midline nucleus located in the lower pons and upper medulla, and the nucleus reticularis paragigantocellularis, located laterally in the medulla. From these nuclei, second-order signals are transmitted down the dorsolateral columns in the spinal cord to

 

(3) a pain inhibitory complex located in the dorsal horns of the spinal cord. At this point, the analgesia signals can block the pain before it is relayed to the brain.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Corticospinal tract: Incorrect. This tract is involved in motor control and voluntary movements, not pain relief.

 

Option C. Medial lemniscus: Incorrect. This pathway carries sensory information related to touch, vibration, and proprioception, not pain relief.

 

Option D. Medial longitudinal fasciculus: Incorrect. This bundle of nerve fibers coordinates eye movements and helps maintain balance, not pain relief.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The periaqueductal gray (PAG) is a critical component of the analgesia system, responsible for relieving pain by sending inhibitory signals to block pain transmission in the spinal cord.

questions.text:
A concerned mother takes her daughter of 14 years age who was complaining of pain in the private parts to a gynecologist. On eliciting history, the girl admits she had consensual sexual intercourse with a neighbor and refuses to get examined. What should the gynecologist do? (AIIMS MAY 2020)

 

  1. Document informed refusal
  2. Do not inform the police
  3. Counsel the mother and daughter
  4. Examine with necessary force
  5. Inform the police
questions.solution:
Ans. C) 1, 3, 5 are true 

 

This situation involves multiple aspects: legal, ethical, and medical considerations are paramount. Here's why each statement is addressed as true or false in this context:

 

1. Document informed refusal: True. It is essential for medical practitioners to document any refusal of examination or treatment, particularly in sensitive cases involving minors. Documentation should include detailed information about what was explained to the patient and the guardian, and their reasons for refusal, to ensure clarity and legal safeguarding.

 

3. Counsel the mother and daughter: True. The role of a gynecologist includes providing medical counseling, especially when it involves minors and sensitive issues such as sexual activity. Counseling should aim to educate about the health implications of the sexual activity, the benefits of medical examination, and the legal aspects considering the age of consent.

 

5. Inform the police: True. According to laws in many jurisdictions, including India, any sexual activity with a minor, regardless of consent, is considered statutory rape. Medical professionals are mandated reporters, which means they are legally obligated to report such cases to law enforcement to ensure the safety of the minor and adhere to legal statutes.

 

Other Options:

 

2. Do not inform the police: False. The gynecologist has a mandatory obligation to report cases of suspected statutory rape, as non-reporting could be considered a failure of duty and legal non-compliance.

 

4. Examine with necessary force: False. It is illegal and unethical to perform a medical examination against a patient's will, especially in the case of a minor. The patient's autonomy must be respected, and no examination should proceed without consent.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Examination of a victim of sexual assault should be done only after the consent of the victim. It is the accused who can be examined without consent, not the victim. Whether the victim agrees for examination or not, the police always have to be informed as there is an allegation of crime of rape (as sex even with consent with a girl <18 years of age will be considered rape)

questions.text: Metabolic acidosis with normal anion gap is seen in all except? (AIIMS NOV 2018)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Salicylate poisoning.

 

Metabolic acidosis can present with either a normal or elevated anion gap. Salicylate poisoning characteristically causes a high anion gap metabolic acidosis due to the accumulation of organic acids like lactic acid and ketoacids. It can initially present with a respiratory alkalosis due to direct stimulation of the respiratory center, followed by metabolic acidosis as the condition progresses.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Proximal RTA (Renal Tubular Acidosis): This causes a normal anion gap (hyperchloremic) metabolic acidosis due to bicarbonate loss in the urine.

 

Option B. Pancreatitis: Can lead to normal anion gap acidosis if associated with diarrhea or other mechanisms leading to bicarbonate loss.

 

Option C. Severe diarrhea: Leads to normal anion gap metabolic acidosis due to significant loss of bicarbonate in stool.

 

Educational Objective:

choices.text: Blunt object with high force doesn’t stimulate nociceptors
Pinching with serrated object stimulate mechanoceptors but doesn’t cause pain
Sharp pain sensation is carried by type C nerve fiber

questions.text: Mechanical nociceptors and its response to a probe with blunt object, pin prick and tooth forceps with serration is recorded as a output of a force transducer coupled to the stimulator. What will you infer from a given diagram? (INICET NOV 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Blunt object with high force doesn't stimulate nociceptors

 

Blunt Object:

 

  • Does not produce action potentials in nociceptors
  • Activates mechanoreceptors without triggering pain sensation
  • High force does not necessarily stimulate nociceptive receptors

 

Pin Prick:

 

  • Produces clear action potentials
  • Stimulates nociceptors
  • Sharp stimuli trigger pain receptors

 

Serrated Forceps:

 

  • Produces multiple action potentials
  • Stimulates both mechanoreceptors and nociceptors
  • Causes significant pain response

 

Sharp pain is typically carried by A-delta fibers

 

Slower, diffuse pain is carried by C fibers

 

Nociceptors respond to potentially tissue-damaging stimuli

 

Educational Objective:

 

Nociceptors (pain receptors) respond differentially to various mechanical stimuli - they are activated by sharp objects and pinching/pressure that can potentially damage tissue, but not by blunt pressure even with high force. Fast, sharp pain is transmitted via A-delta fibers, while slow, dull pain is transmitted via C fibers.

questions.text: Match the following cells with their locations: (INICET NOV 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) 1-b, 2-a, 3-c, 4-d  

 

The correct matches for the cells and their respective locations are as follows:

 

  1. Kupffer cells (b) Liver: Kupffer cells are specialized macrophages located in the liver, involved in the breakdown of red blood cells and the immune response within the liver.
  2. Parietal cells (a) Stomach: Parietal cells are found in the lining of the stomach and are responsible for secreting hydrochloric acid (HCl), which aids in digestion.
  3. Dust cells (c) Alveoli: Dust cells, also known as alveolar macrophages, are found in the alveoli of the lungs. They play a crucial role in removing inhaled particles and pathogens from the alveolar spaces.
  4. Clara cells (d) Bronchioles: Clara cells, now more commonly referred to as club cells, are found in the bronchioles of the lungs. They secrete surfactant proteins and detoxify harmful substances inhaled into the lungs.

 

Educational Objective:

questions.text: A patient with chronic kidney disease has the following laboratory reports. Calculate the anion gap in this patient. Na+: 145 mEq/L, K+ 4 mEq/L Cl: 90 mEq/L HCO3: 20 mEq/L. (INICET MAY 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) 35


The anion gap is calculated using the formula:

 

Anion Gap = Na−(Cl+HCO3)
 

Anion Gap=145−(90+20)=35

 

Educational Objective:

 

The anion gap is calculated as Na - (Cl + HCO3), and a high anion gap may indicate metabolic acidosis.

questions.text: Which of the following is a gram-positive organism that shows the following appearance on Ziehl-Neelsen staining? (INICET NOV 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Nocardia

 

The characteristic morphology of Nocardia is a branching, filamentous, gram-positive rod when observed under the microscope. Nocardia can resemble Actinomyces species on gram stain.  However, Nocardia is an obligate aerobe that stains weakly positive on acid-fast staining.

 

Nocardia is typically weakly acid-fast after traditional carbol-fuchsin staining and positive on modified acid-fast staining due to the presence of mycolic acid in the cell wall. Unlike mycobacteria (also acid-fast positive), Nocardia has a “beaded” appearance on acid-fast staining. Nocardia is catalase-positive and urease positive.

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Mycobacterium tuberculosis bacilli are acid fast but non-branching

 

 

Option C. Mycobacterium leprae bacilli are less acid and alcohol fast than the tubercle bacillus; therefore, 10% sulphuric acid is used as a decolorizer in place of acid/alcohol solution.

 

 

Option D. Actinomyces are gram-positive but non-acid-fast in contrast to Nocardia.

 

The following image shows the filamentous gram-positive stained actinomyces:

 

 

Educational Objective:

 

Nocardia can be identified by its branching filamentous structure on gram stain and weak acid-fast positivity due to the presence of mycolic acid in its cell wall, distinguishing it from other gram-positive and acid-fast organisms.

questions.text: Under anaerobic metabolism which of the following substrates yields 3 molecules of ATP? (AIIMS Nov 2017)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Glycogen

 

Breakdown of glycogen yields glucose-6-phosphate which can enter the glycolysis pathway bypassing the first step thus saving one ATP and producing 3 ATPs.

 

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Amino acid: Amino acids are not directly involved in anaerobic glycolysis and do not yield ATP through this pathway.

 

Option C. Glucose: The glycolysis of one glucose molecule under anaerobic conditions yields a net gain of 2 ATP molecules, not 3, because the initial phosphorylation step consumes one ATP.

 

Option D. Galactose: Galactose is converted to glucose-6-phosphate, but this conversion involves steps that consume ATP, resulting in a net gain similar to that of glucose, which is 2 ATP molecules.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Under anaerobic conditions, glycogen yields 3 molecules of ATP per glucose unit because it enters glycolysis as glucose-6-phosphate, bypassing the initial ATP-consuming step of glycolysis.

questions.text: Which of the following bony structures is present behind the marked area? (INICET Nov 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. B. Lesser wing of sphenoid

 

The pterion is a point on the side of the skull where several bones meet, including the frontal, parietal, temporal, and sphenoid bones. The lesser wing of the sphenoid is one of the bones that contributes to the formation of the pterion. It's an important landmark because it's located just behind the pterion.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Post clivus: The clivus is a bony ridge on the occipital bone, and it is located at the base of the skull. The "post clivus" isn't a commonly used term in anatomy, and it's not directly related to the pterion.

 

Option C. Sella turcica: The sella turcica is a saddle-shaped depression in the sphenoid bone where the pituitary gland is located. It is situated more toward the center of the skull, behind the eyes and nasal cavity, and is not directly related to the pterion.

 

Option D. Carotid canal: The carotid canal is a passage in the temporal bone that houses the internal carotid artery. It is located deeper within the skull, closer to the middle ear, and is not directly related to the pterion.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The pterion is an H-shaped sutural junction between four bones of the skull:

 

1. Frontal bone

2. Squamous part of the temporal bone

3. Greater wing of the sphenoid bone

4. Parietal bone

choices.text: Loss of soft tissue planes is the earliest X-ray change of infection
Glass pieces can be seen as radiopaque in X-ray images
Cartilage is not visualized on X-ray.
Live bone is more radio-opaque than dead bone on X- Ray

questions.text: Which of the following statements are false regarding X Rays? (AIIMS MAY 2018)
questions.solution:
Ans. D. Live bone is more radio-opaque than dead bone on X- Ray images.

 

Explanation:

 

On X-ray imaging, dead bones are whiter (more radio-opaque) than live bone due to absence of bone resorption activity as vascular demineralization is lost. This is known as sequestrum.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Loss of soft tissue planes is the earliest X-ray change of infection: This statement is true. The loss of definition of soft tissue planes due to swelling or fluid accumulation is often the earliest radiographic sign of infection, typically appearing within 24-48 hours after disease onset.

 

Option B. Glass pieces can be seen as radiopaque on X-ray images: This is true. Glass, especially if it contains lead, shows up as radiopaque on X-rays, making it visible.

 

Option C. Cartilage is not visualized on X-ray: This is true. Cartilage itself does not appear on X-rays because it does not absorb X-rays well; the space where cartilage is located appears radiolucent, which is often perceived as joint space.

 

Educational Objective:


On X-ray imaging, dead bone appears more radio-opaque than live bone due to the lack of resorption activity. Understanding these differences is crucial for correctly interpreting radiologic findings related to bone vitality and infection.

questions.text: A young patient with RTA sustained an open fracture of femur which was operated and stabilized as shown below. Identify the fixator.(AIIMS NOV 2019)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Rail fixator

 

OPEN FRACTURES

 

  • An open fracture occurs when the bone breaks through the skin.
  • These typically result from high-energy injuries and are often associated with significant damage to the surrounding soft tissues and contamination of the wound.
  • Phalanges followed by tibia is the most common site.
  • These injuries are classified into three types according to the Gustillo-Anderson

 

 

  • These injuries require immediate administration of antibiotics and irrigation and debridement of the wound.
  • The goal of the treatment is to achieve fracture healing and to prevent wound infections and osteomyelitis.
  • When the wound is contaminated, an external fixator is initially used.
  • Early coverage of the wound is important to avoid infection.
  • In general, an increase in Gustillo grade is associated with an increase in infection risk.
  • External Fixation:
    • In external fixation the fixation device is external to skin-external fixator or Ilizarov fixator.
    • Ilizarov fixator works on the principles of distraction osteogenesis that is an osteotomy is carried out and distracted at the rate of 1 mm per day causing distraction at the callus and subsequently lengthening can be done. It can be used for correction of deformities like malunion, shortening, shortening with discharging sinus, gap non-union and also for CTEV.
    • Open fracture is one of the most common cause for segmental loss of bone.
    • For treating bone gap when Ilizarov ring fixator is used, it achieves union, eradicates infection, corrects deformities, reestablishes limb length and at the same time maintains function.
    • The Rail Fixator is designed for bone transport for reconstructing bone loss following open fracture and sequestrectomy following osteomyelitis. It provides correction through bone transport, compression-distraction and bifocal lengthening. 

 

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. K-nail. Femoral shaft fractures are one of the commonest high energy fractures, and intramedullary nailing is the gold standard management of these fractures. Intramedullary fixation is considered superior to plate fixation because of lower rates of infection, early weight-bearing, and lesser chances of non-union. Unlocked Kuntscher nail (K-nail) should only be used for isthmic femoral shaft fractures. The main drawback of K-nail for use in other types of femoral shaft fracture was lack of rotational stability. Nowadays, interlocking intramedullary nail is used for almost all types of femoral shaft fractures because of better rotational stability.

 

 

Option C. Ilizarov fixator. Ilizarov fixator is an effective treatment modality of open comminuted femur fractures with high union rate, adequate alignment and satisfactory functional outcomes. Ilizarov fixator works on the principles of distraction osteogenesis that is an osteotomy is carried out and distracted at the rate of 1 mm per day causing distraction at the callus and subsequently lengthening can be done. It can be used for correction of deformities like malunion, shortening, shortening with discharging sinus, gap non-union and also for CTEV. For treating bone gap when Ilizarov ring fixator is used, it achieves union, eradicates infection, corrects deformities, reestablishes limb length and at the same time maintains function.

 

 

Option D. Proximal femoral nail. The proximal femoral nail (PFN) is an osteosynthetic implant is used to treat proximal femoral fractures in the trochanter area with a closed intramedullary fixation method. It consists of a funnel-shaped intramedullary nail with slight bending to reflect proximal femoral diaphyseal trochanteric morphology. It has two proximal openings, a larger one distally for a large femoral neck lag screw and a smaller one immediately above for a smaller anti-rotation screw/pin. There are small holes at the distal end of the nail for locking screws.  It can be combined with a wire cerclage with an open reduction for additional stability in complicated subtrochanteric fractures.

 

 

Educational Objective:

 

The fixator shown in the image in the question is a Rail Fixator, used to treat open fractures to fill the bone gap.

choices.text: Respiratory acidosis, hyperventilation, inadequate metabolic compensation
Respiratory alkalosis, hypoventilation, inadequate metabolic compensation
Respiratory acidosis, hypoventilation, inadequate metabolic compensation
Respiratory acidosis, hypoventilation, adequate metabolic compensation

questions.text: A 60-year-old with a history of COPD is brought to the ER with worsening dyspnea. ABG was done and pH was 7.3, pCO2 was 60 mmHg with HCO3- being 28 mEq/L. Which of the following is seen in this patient? (INICET Nov 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Respiratory acidosis, hypoventilation, inadequate metabolic compensation

 

Explanation:  

 

The patient's arterial blood gas (ABG) shows a pH of 7.3, indicating acidosis (normal pH: 7.35-7.45). The elevated pCO2 of 60 mmHg (normal: 35-45 mmHg) points to a respiratory cause of the acidosis, specifically respiratory acidosis. In COPD patients, chronic CO2 retention is common, leading to increased bicarbonate (HCO3-) levels as a compensatory mechanism. However, in acute respiratory acidosis, the metabolic compensation is typically inadequate, as seen by the HCO3- level of 28 mEq/L (normal: 22-28 mEq/L). The inadequate compensation suggests an acute exacerbation rather than a chronic condition, as chronic respiratory acidosis would have a more elevated bicarbonate level (>30 mEq/L).

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Respiratory acidosis, hyperventilation, inadequate metabolic compensation: Hyperventilation leads to respiratory alkalosis, not acidosis. The patient's presentation does not fit this scenario.

 

Option B. Respiratory alkalosis, hypoventilation, inadequate metabolic compensation: Hypoventilation causes respiratory acidosis, not alkalosis. This choice is incorrect.

 

Option D. Respiratory acidosis, hypoventilation, adequate metabolic compensation: Adequate metabolic compensation would show higher bicarbonate levels (>30 mEq/L). The patient's bicarbonate level indicates inadequate compensation, ruling out this option.

 

Educational Objective:

 

In acute respiratory acidosis due to COPD exacerbation, expect hypoventilation and inadequate metabolic compensation, indicated by elevated pCO2 and only slightly elevated HCO3- levels.

questions.text: Identify the person to whom the First-hand knowledge rule is applicable? (AIIMS May 2018)
questions.solution:
Ans. A. Common witness

 

The first-hand knowledge rule applies to a common witness who gives evidence about the facts directly observed by them. This rule ensures that the testimony provided is based on direct observation and personal experience rather than hearsay or second-hand information.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Handwriting expert: An expert witness who provides testimony based on specialized knowledge or expertise, rather than direct personal observation of the facts in question.

 

Option C. Doctor: A medical professional who may provide expert testimony based on their medical expertise, rather than direct observation of the facts in question.

 

Option D. A hostile witness is a witness who appears to be refusing to fully testify in support of the person who called them or testifies in a way that significantly differs from their pre-trial.

 

Note : An expert witness is a person with extensive experience or knowledge in a specific field or discipline beyond that expected from a layperson. The expert witness's duty is to apply their expertise to give a professional opinion to the tribunal or court on particular matters in dispute. Doctors, handwriting/ fingerprints/ firearms experts come under this category.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The first-hand knowledge rule ensures that the testimony provided by a common witness is based on direct observation and personal experience, thereby maintaining the integrity and reliability of the evidence presented in court.

choices.text: Severe acidosis with elevated BUN and creatinine

questions.text: A patient with CKD with refractory hypertension is brought to the casualty with dizziness. His BP was found to be 200/120 mmHg. His BUN was 50 mg/dl and creatinine was 3 mg/dl. Potassium was 6 mEq/L. Which of the following is an indication of emergency hemodialysis? (INICET Nov 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Severe acidosis with elevated BUN and creatinine

 

Emergency hemodialysis is indicated in several critical conditions commonly remembered with the mnemonic AEIOU:

 

  1. Acidosis: Severe metabolic acidosis that is not responsive to standard medical therapy, particularly when the pH is less than 7.1.
  2. Electrolyte imbalance: Severe hyperkalemia, especially when potassium levels are more than 6.5 mEq/L, rapidly rising, or refractory to medical management.
  3. Intoxications: With dialyzable drugs.
  4. Overload: Volume overload state, such as diuretic-resistant pulmonary edema, particularly when oxygen requirements are increasing.
  5. Uremia: Uremic complications such as pericarditis or encephalopathy, which are urgent indications due to the risk of tamponade or severe cognitive impairment.

 

In this patient, severe acidosis, alongside elevated BUN and creatinine, is a strong indication for emergency hemodialysis.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Hypertension: Hypertension alone, even when severe, is not an immediate indication for emergency hemodialysis

 

Option C. Potassium level of 6 mEq/L: While elevated, a potassium level of 6 mEq/L by itself is not enough to indicate emergency dialysis unless it is rapidly rising or refractory to treatment. Typically, levels above 6.5 mEq/L are considered more critical.

 

Option D. Metabolic alkalosis: This is not an indication for emergency hemodialysis. Instead, metabolic acidosis, especially when severe and refractory to treatment, is a more significant concern.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Emergency hemodialysis is indicated for severe acidosis, refractory hyperkalemia, volume overload, intoxications, and uremic complications. Severe acidosis with elevated BUN and creatinine is a critical indication for initiating emergency hemodialysis.

questions.text: A 22-year-old man has arrived with a gradual swelling on the left side of his face persisting for two weeks. He had a prior incident of trauma involving wood, which occurred two months ago. A contrast-enhanced CT scan of the nasal passages and paranasal sinuses reveals a mass within the subcutaneous tissue of the left cheek. Examination of a tissue sample obtained via biopsy indicates the presence of a foreign body granuloma, with positive staining observed using PAS and GMS methods. What is the likely diagnosis? (INICET May 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Phycomycosis

The given clinical scenario points to a diagnosis of Phycomycosis /Mucormycosis. GMS positive confirms this.

It is fungal infection which may prove rapidly fatal. It is seen in uncontrolled diabetics or in those taking immunosuppressive drugs. 

Other Options:

Option A. Midline lethal granuloma: This is a term historically used to describe aggressive midline facial granulomatous diseases, often linked to conditions like granulomatosis with polyangiitis (Wegener's granulomatosis). It does not fit the biopsy findings or clinical scenario described here.

Option B. Foreign body granuloma: Although the biopsy indicates the presence of a foreign body granuloma, the positive PAS and GMS staining suggests a fungal etiology, which is characteristic of Phycomycosis.

Option D. IgG4 granuloma: This is associated with IgG4-related disease, which presents with different clinical and histopathological findings, not typically involving PAS and GMS positive fungal elements.

Educational Objective:

Phycomycosis should be considered in patients with a history of trauma, swelling, and positive fungal stains (PAS and GMS), particularly if they have underlying conditions like diabetes or immunosuppression.

questions.text: Which of the following procedure is shown in the image given below? (INICET May 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Anterior ethmoidal nerve block

 

The procedure shown in the given image is an anterior ethmoidal nerve block.

 

The anterior ethmoidal nerve supplies the roof of the nasal cavity. It is a branch of the Nasociliary nerve which in turn is a branch of the ophthalmic nerve (V1). It is sometimes used in endonasal surgery.

 

Detailing the Procedure:

 

  • Purpose: Used predominantly to numb the area for surgical procedures within the nasal cavity.
  • Method: Involves injection near the anterior ethmoidal foramen to block the nerve that transmits sensation from the nasal roof.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Nasolacrimal duct syringing: This procedure is used to check the patency of the nasolacrimal duct. It involves flushing the duct with saline to check for blockages, typically conducted by inserting a syringe into the puncta near the medial canthus of the eye. However, this is not related to the procedure shown in the image since it involves the eye directly and is performed with the eyes open to access the puncta.

 

Option C. Infraorbital nerve block: This block anesthetizes the area supplied by the infraorbital nerve, which affects the lower eyelid, upper lip, and cheek. It is generally performed via an intraoral approach at the infraorbital foramen, located below the orbit, which is not depicted in the image.

 

Option D. Trephination of the frontal sinus: This surgical procedure involves making an incision in the floor of the frontal sinus to facilitate drainage. This procedure targets a different anatomic location and involves surgical tools, not the approach shown in the image.

 

Educational Objective:

 

An anterior ethmoidal nerve block is crucial for numbing the nasal cavity area, particularly in endonasal surgeries. It is essential for procedures requiring detailed work near the roof of the nasal cavity, reflecting the significance of understanding the specific nerve anatomy for effective anesthesia.

questions.text: Which of the following can be given for long term management of obesity?
questions.solution:
Ans. A. Liraglutide

 

Liraglutide is an injectable medication originally developed to treat type 2 diabetes but has also been approved for weight management in obesity. It works by mimicking the hormone GLP-1, which regulates appetite and calorie intake. Liraglutide has been shown to be effective for long-term weight management and is considered a viable option for obesity treatment.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Metformin: While metformin is primarily used to treat type 2 diabetes, it has been observed to cause modest weight loss in some people. However, it is not primarily indicated for the treatment of obesity and is usually not the first choice solely for weight management.

 

Option C. Sibutramine: Sibutramine was previously used as an appetite suppressant for weight loss, but it has been withdrawn from the market in many countries due to cardiovascular safety concerns. Therefore, it is no longer recommended for obesity treatment.

 

Option D. Fenfluramine: Part of the fen-phen combination, fenfluramine was used for weight loss but was withdrawn from the market due to serious side effects, particularly heart valve issues. Like sibutramine, it is no longer considered safe or appropriate for obesity treatment.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Liraglutide is a viable and approved option for the long-term management of obesity. It works by mimicking the hormone GLP-1 to help regulate appetite and reduce calorie intake. Other Options like sibutramine and fenfluramine have been withdrawn from the market due to safety concerns, and metformin, while causing modest weight loss, is not primarily indicated for obesity treatment.

questions.text: Identify the plant given in the image below? (INICET MAY 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. B. Argemone Mexicana

 

  • The plant in the image is Argemone Mexicana.
  • It is also called as Mexican prickly poppy.
  • Oil extract can cause Epidemic dropsy characterized by vomiting, diarrhea, edema of the feet, and generalized anasarca.
  • Identification: Yellow flowers

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Datura alba: Datura alba, also known as white datura, has large trumpet-shaped white flowers and is a different plant with its own toxic properties, primarily affecting the nervous system.

 

 

Option C. Abrus precatorius: Abrus precatorius, commonly known as Rosary pea or jequirity, has distinctive red seeds with a black spot. The plant is different from Argemone mexicana.

 

 

Option D. Erthyroxylum coca: Erthyroxylum coca is the plant from which cocaine is derived. It has small white flowers and red berries, and does not resemble Argemone mexicana.

 

 

Educational Objective:

 

The plant Argemone mexicana, identifiable by its yellow flowers and spiny leaves, is known for its toxic oil extract which can cause Epidemic dropsy.

questions.text:
Identify the incorrectly matched pair(s) of pharyngeal arch and its artery?

 

  1. 1st arch - Maxillary artery
  2. 2nd arch - Hyoid and stapedial artery
  3. 3rd arch - Common carotid and proximal internal carotid artery
  4. 4th arch - Subclavian artery
  5. 6th arch - Aorta on the left side
questions.solution:
Ans.  C. v

 

Explanation

 

All the given pairs of pharyngeal arteries and their arteries are correctly matched except for 'v' (option C).

 

The 6th pharyngeal arch has its blood supply on the left side from the left pulmonary artery and ductus arteriosus, not from the aorta.

 

Other options

 

  1. 1st arch - Maxillary artery: Correct. The maxillary artery is indeed a derivative of the first pharyngeal arch.
  2. 2nd arch - Hyoid and stapedial artery: Correct. The hyoid artery (or the stapedial artery in its embryonic context) is derived from the second pharyngeal arch.
  3. 3rd arch - Common carotid and proximal internal carotid artery: Correct. The third pharyngeal arch gives rise to portions of the common carotid artery and the proximal part of the internal carotid artery.
  4. 4th arch - Subclavian artery: Correct on the right side. The fourth pharyngeal arch is associated with the development of the right subclavian artery and part of the aortic arch on the left side.

 

Educational Objective

questions.text: A decrease in GFR is associated with which of the following? (INICET MAY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Decreased Bowman's oncotic pressure

 

If the hydrostatic pressure of the capillaries or the oncotic pressure of the Bowman's capsule decreases, filtration will decrease. If the oncotic pressure in the glomerular capillary increases or if the hydrostatic pressure in the Bowman's capsule increases, GFR will decrease as well.

 

Other Options:

 

Glomerular filtration rate (GFR) is determined by the net filtration pressure, which depends on various pressures within the glomerulus and Bowman's capsule:

 

Option A. Increased Renal Blood Flow: This increases GFR as more blood flow leads to higher filtration.

 

Option B. Increased Glomerular Hydrostatic Pressure: This also increases GFR because higher pressure in the glomerulus drives more filtrate into Bowman's capsule.

 

Option D. Decreased Glomerular Oncotic Pressure: This increases GFR because lower protein concentration in the glomerulus reduces the opposing force to filtration.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Decreased Bowman's capsule oncotic pressure reduces net filtration pressure (NFP) and decreases glomerular filtration rate (GFR). Increased Bowman's capsule oncotic pressure increases filtration pressure and GFR.

questions.text: What is the value of normal Glomerular oncotic pressure?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) 32 mmHg

 

The value of normal Glomerular capillary oncotic pressure is 32 mmHg.

 

Oncotic pressure, or colloid osmotic-pressure, is a form of osmotic pressure induced by the proteins, notably albumin, in a blood vessel's plasma (blood/liquid. that causes a pull-on fluid back into the capillary. Participating colloids displace water molecules, thus creating a relative water molecule deficit with water molecules moving back into the circulatory system within the lower venous pressure end of capillaries.

 

It is mostly negligible, but sometimes can be as high as 6 mmHg in the brain. The values are also positive in the liver and kidneys.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The normal glomerular oncotic pressure is approximately 32 mmHg, which helps maintain fluid balance by drawing water back into the capillaries.

choices.text: The maximum buffering capacity of the compound is represented by points A and B
﻿﻿﻿The points A and B represent the range of maximum ionization of the amine and carboxyl group
﻿﻿﻿The compound has three ionisable side chains
﻿﻿﻿The compound has one ionisable group

questions.text: The graph shown below is the titration curve of a biochemical compound. Which of the following statement is true?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) The maximum buffering capacity of the compound is represented by points A and B

 

The maximum buffering capacity of the compound is represented by points A and B, which corresponds to the pk1, and pk2 of the compound.

 

The above graph resembles the titration curve of the amino acid glycine.

 

Titration curve of Glycine:

 

 

The titration is completed at a pH of 12, where the glycine predominantly exists in the form of H2N - CH2 - COO.

 

pK1, and pK2, correspond to the point where the buffering capacity is maximum.

 

Characteristics of the titration curve:

  • ﻿﻿Buffering capacity is referred to as the ability of the amino acid to resist the change in pH due to the addition of acid (H+) or base (OH- equivalents), by accepting or losing the protons respectively.
  • ﻿﻿An ionizable group refers to the group which can either lose or accept a proton and becomes negatively charged or positively charged ion respectively.
  • ﻿﻿During the titration, the buffering capacity of the compound reaches its maximum, at points where the pKa of the ionizable groups is reached.
  • ﻿﻿Each of these pKa are labeled as pK1, pK2, pK3, etc.
  • ﻿﻿The presence of two pKs indicates that the compound has two ionizable groups. Ex. Glycine.
  • ﻿﻿The presence of three or more pKs indicates the presence of side chains on the amino acid, with additional ionizable groups.
  • ﻿﻿Ex. histidine has three ionizable groups, an amino group, an imidazole group (on the side chain), and a carboxyl group. The pKas of these groups respectively correspond to the pK1, pK2, pK3 of the titration curve of histidine.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. The points A and B represent the range of maximum ionization of the amine and carboxyl group: Points A and B represent the pKa values, not the range of maximum ionization. The range of maximum ionization would be broader than just the pKa points.

 

Option C. The compound has three ionisable side chains: The graph shows two pKa values, indicating two ionizable groups. A compound with three ionizable groups would have three pKa values.

 

Option D. The compound has one ionisable group: The graph shows two pKa values, indicating two ionizable groups (an amino group and a carboxyl group).

 

Educational Objective:

 

The points A and B on the titration curve represent the maximum buffering capacity of the compound, corresponding to the pKa values of the ionizable groups. The graph shown likely represents an amino acid like glycine, which has two ionizable groups.

questions.text: During a major disaster response, the medical team in an emergency department needs to prioritize patients based on the severity of their injuries and their medical needs. This prioritization process is known as triage. Each patient is assigned a specific color code representing their current state and the urgency of their medical attention. Which of the following correctly matches the color designation with its corresponding level of patient priority in the triage process? [AIIMS MAY 2017]
questions.solution:
Ans. (c) Green – ambulatory

 

  • Triage is a critical process used in emergency medicine to quickly classify patients according to the severity of their health condition and the urgency of their need for care.
  • The color-coding system is a standardized approach used globally, with each color representing a specific category of priority:
  • Green indicates "ambulatory" patients, who are those with relatively minor injuries or conditions that do not require immediate, life-saving intervention.
  • These patients can often walk and may have injuries such as infections, closed fractures, minor abrasions, and lacerations.

 

Educational Objective:

questions.text: A morbidly obese diabetic woman is not responsive to metformin therapy. She has a history of pancreatitis and family history of bladder cancer. She does not want to take injections. Which of the following would be suitable to reduce her glucose levels? (AIIMS NOV 2018)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Canagliflozin

 

Canagliflozin is a suitable oral medication for a diabetic patient not responding to metformin, especially when she has a history of pancreatitis and a family history of bladder cancer, and prefers to avoid injectable medications. Canagliflozin works by inhibiting the sodium-glucose co-transporter 2 (SGLT2), which helps the kidneys excrete glucose through urine, thus lowering blood glucose levels

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Sitagliptin: Not ideal as it has been associated with a risk of acute pancreatitis, which poses a significant risk given her medical history.

 

Option B. Pioglitazone: Should be avoided due to its potential link with bladder cancer, especially considering her family history.

 

Option D. Liraglutide: Although effective in managing diabetes, it is not suitable as it is an injectable medication and the patient prefers to avoid injections. Moreover, it also carries a risk of pancreatitis.

 

Educational Objective:

 

In choosing diabetes medications for patients with specific health concerns, it's crucial to consider both the efficacy and the side-effect profile of the drug, as well as patient preferences for administration methods to ensure compliance and safety. Canagliflozin is an appropriate choice for this patient due to its oral administration and lower risk concerning her medical history.

questions.text: A resident in neurology is assessing a patient who recently sustained a traumatic brain injury using the Glasgow Coma Scale (GCS). How should the resident describe the type of data obtained from the GCS? [INICET NOV 2020]
questions.solution:
Ans. (b) Ordinal scale data

 

  • The Glasgow Coma Scale represents ordinal data since the GCS score is categorized as mild, moderate, or severe, following a specific order of severity.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Nominal scale data: Data based on names without a specific order.

 

Option C. Alphanumerical data: Data that includes both letters and numbers, not applicable here.

 

Option D. Interval scale data: Data measured along a scale where each point is equidistant from the next, but GCS does not meet this criterion.

 

Educational Objective:

questions.text: A 65-year-old man presents to the emergency department with signs of shock. The attending physician decides to calculate the Modified Shock Index to better assess the patient's condition and predict the risk of mortality. Which of the following parameters is used to calculate the Modified Shock Index?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) HR/MAP

 

The Modified Shock Index (MSI) is calculated as Heart Rate (HR) divided by Mean Arterial Pressure (MAP). It has been shown to be a better predictor of mortality in patients with shock than the original Shock Index. MAP provides a more accurate assessment of tissue perfusion, as it reflects the overall blood pressure status more comprehensively than systolic blood pressure (SBP) alone.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. HR/SBP: This is the original Shock Index, which calculates the ratio of heart rate to systolic blood pressure. While useful, the Modified Shock Index (HR/MAP) is considered a better predictor of patient outcomes.

 

Option B. HR/DBP: Diastolic blood pressure (DBP) is not used in the calculation of the Modified Shock Index.

 

Option D. PR/SBP: Pulse rate (PR) and systolic blood pressure (SBP) are not used together to calculate the Modified Shock Index.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • The Modified Shock Index (MSI) is calculated using heart rate (HR) divided by mean arterial pressure (MAP), and it is a more sensitive indicator of hemodynamic stability and mortality in shock compared to the original Shock Index (HR/SBP).
  • MAP provides a better assessment of tissue perfusion and disease severity in critically ill patients.

questions.text: Match the wood lamp findings with the respective diseases: (INICET MAY 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) 1-e,2-c,3-d,4-b

 

Erythrasma (1-e): Shows a characteristic coral red fluorescence under Wood's lamp. This fluorescence is due to the production of porphyrins by Corynebacterium minutissimum, the bacteria responsible for erythrasma.

 

Pityriasis versicolor (2-c): Typically displays a yellow fluorescence. The causative yeast, Malassezia, can produce metabolites that fluoresce under a Wood's lamp.

 

Tinea Capitis (3-d): Often shows a blue fluorescence. The fungi causing tinea capitis, like species of Microsporum, can fluoresce blue due to the presence of certain metabolic byproducts in the fungal cell walls.

 

Vitiligo (4-b): Exhibits a milky white fluorescence. This is because the areas affected by vitiligo lack melanin, making the skin appear distinctly brighter under the UV light of a Wood's lamp compared to normal skin.

 

 

Educational Objective:

 

 

Wood's lamp is a useful diagnostic tool in dermatology for visualizing certain fungal and bacterial infections, as well as pigmentary disorders. The specific color of fluorescence can guide clinicians in making a preliminary diagnosis, which must be confirmed with additional tests or clinical evaluation.

questions.text: A patient came with complaints of high-grade fever & altered sensorium. He was diagnosed to be suffering from meningococcal meningitis. Which of the following is the most appropriate empirical treatment? (AIIMS NOV 2017)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Ceftriaxone

 

Ceftriaxone or cefotaxime is the drug of choice for empirical treatment of meningococcal meningitis. However, Penicillin G remains the antibiotic of choice for susceptible strains.

 

Empirical antimicrobial therapy is initiated in with patients with suspected bacterial meningitis before the results of CSF Gram stain and culture are known.

 

S. pneumoniae and N. meningitidis are the most common etiologic organism of community acquired bacterial meningitis. Due to the emergence of penicillin resistant and cephalosporin resistant S. pneumoniae, empirical therapy of community acquired suspected bacterial meningitis should include a combination of –

 

  • Dexamethasone
  • Third or fourth generation cephalosporin (E.g., ceftriaxone, cefotaxime or Cefepime)
  • Vancomycin
  • Acyclovir- HSV Encephalitis is the main differential
  • Doxycycline –during tick season

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Penicillin G: While effective against Neisseria meningitidis, it is not the first choice for empirical treatment due to broader resistance concerns and coverage needs in initial therapy settings.

 

Option C. Cefotetan and D. Cefoxitin: These are second-generation cephalosporins, which are not typically used for the treatment of meningococcal meningitis due to insufficient CNS penetration and coverage compared to third-generation cephalosporins like ceftriaxone.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Ceftriaxone is the preferred empirical therapy for meningococcal meningitis due to its effective CNS penetration, broad antibacterial coverage, and favorable dosing regimen. Immediate initiation of empirical therapy is crucial in suspected bacterial meningitis to prevent severe outcomes.

questions.text: Combination of appearance in CTEV (Congenital Talipes Equinovarus) is:
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Equinus, inversion, forefoot adduction, cavus

 

In congenital talipes equinovarus (CTEV), or idiopathic clubfoot, the deformity involves equinus, inversion, forefoot adduction, and cavus. CTEV is a congenital malformation of the foot and is predominantly seen in male children. The calf and medial foot tissues are underdeveloped.

 

Components of the deformity:

 

  1. Cavus: This deformity occurs due to exaggerated arching of the foot at the mid-tarsal joint.
  2. Adduction: This deformity occurs at the talonavicular joint.
  3. Inversion: This deformity occurs at the subtalar joint, where the calcaneus is inverted, leading to a medially facing sole.
  4. Equinus: This deformity occurs at the ankle joint and tarsal joints, causing plantar flexion.

 

The equinovarus deformity causes inward twisting of the foot, with the sole facing posteromedially in severe cases. Associated disorders like hip dislocation and spina bifida should be evaluated.

 

Treatment:

 

  • Ponseti's method is a successful manipulation technique for CTEV. It begins as early as the first 2 weeks after birth, involving weekly manipulation of the foot using plaster casts. Ponseti’s method follows the correction order: Cavus-adduction-varus-equinus (CAVE).
  • Typically, five casts are required for correction, followed by bracing to maintain the corrected position. Foot abduction brace (FAB) is used initially full-time and then at night for up to 4 years to prevent relapse.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Equinus, eversion, forefoot adduction, cavus: This option is incorrect as the deformity involves inversion, not eversion.

 

Option C. Equinus, eversion, forefoot abduction, cavus: This option is incorrect because forefoot adduction is the correct deformity pattern, not abduction, and inversion, not eversion.

 

Option D. Equinus, inversion, forefoot adduction, planus: While this option correctly includes equinus, inversion, and adduction, it incorrectly describes the foot as planus (flat). In CTEV, there is cavus, or an exaggerated arch.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The deformity in Congenital Talipes Equinovarus (CTEV) consists of equinus, inversion, forefoot adduction, and cavus. Early detection and treatment using Ponseti’s method can correct the deformity and prevent long-term complications.

choices.text: Radical/ wide excision of GB fossa

questions.text: A patent underwent laparoscopic cholecystectomy. The histopathology specimen reveals carcinoma with invasion into the muscularis propria. What is the next best step? (INICET Nov 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Radical/ wide excision of GB fossa

 

  • In the scenario of a patient with a gallbladder carcinoma discovered incidentally following a laparoscopic cholecystectomy, where the carcinoma has invaded the muscularis propria, the next step in management should focus on ensuring complete removal of any residual malignant tissue and preventing local recurrence.
  • Radical or wide excision of the gallbladder fossa is the recommended course of action. This involves excising the gallbladder bed to the level of the liver parenchyma and possibly lymph node dissection to ensure any potential spread or residual disease is addressed. This approach is supported by the need to achieve negative margins, as gallbladder cancer can be aggressive and has a tendency to infiltrate the liver and surrounding structures.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Radiotherapy and B. Chemotherapy might be considered as adjunct therapies depending on the stage of the cancer, pathological findings from the re-excision, and the patient's overall health status. However, they are not the primary step immediately following the discovery of invasive gallbladder cancer in a post-cholecystectomy specimen.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Radical/wide excision of the GB fossa is indeed the appropriate next step to prevent local recurrence and potentially improve survival outcomes. This decision is based on the depth of tumor invasion and the general aggressiveness of gallbladder cancers.

questions.text: A patient presents with urethral discharge. A gram stain smear is made from the discharge sample and the following microscopic image is seen. What is the most likely causative organism? (INICET NOV 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Neisseria gonorrhea

 

The clinic history along with microscopic image is suggestive of Neisseria gonorrhea.

 

Gram-negative, intracellular, cocci, usually seen in pairs (diplococci) with the adjacent sides flattened (typically kidney-shaped); (Looks like two coffee beans kissing).

 

In urethral discharge, it is predominately found within the polymorphs.

 

Gonococci do not contain capsules (meningococci do).

 

Virulence factors -

 

  • Pili: Pili mediate attachment to mucosal cell surfaces and also are antiphagocytic. Piliated gonococci are usually virulent, whereas nonpiliated strains are avirulent.
  • Lipooligosaccharides (LOS)
  • Outer membrane proteins and Opa proteins eg. Porin A: mediates invasion of the epithelial cells.
  • IgA protease hydrolyzes secretory IgA, which could otherwise block the attachment of Neisseria gonorrheae to the mucosa.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Trichomonas: Trichomonas vaginalis is a flagellated protozoan and not a gram-negative diplococcus.

 

Option B. Chlamydia trachomatis: Causes urethritis but is an obligate intracellular bacterium that does not show the gram-negative diplococcus morphology.

 

Option D. Gardnerella: Associated with bacterial vaginosis and presents as gram-variable coccobacilli, not gram-negative diplococci.

 

Educational Objective :

 

The presence of gram-negative, intracellular, kidney-shaped diplococci in urethral discharge is characteristic of Neisseria gonorrhea, a common causative agent of sexually transmitted infections resulting in urethritis.

questions.text: Stage the bedsore in the following image: (AIIMS NOV 2019)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) 4

 

The image depicts a Stage 4 pressure ulcer (bedsore), which is characterized by deep tissue loss that exposes underlying structures such as muscle, bone, or supporting tissues. Stage 4 is the most severe form of pressure ulcer, often showing significant tissue necrosis, deep crater formation, and the possibility of undermining or tunneling under the skin.

 

 

Educational Objective: 

 

Stage 4 pressure ulcers are characterized by full-thickness tissue loss with visible muscle, bone, or supporting structures, making them the most severe and challenging to manage.

questions.text:
An internist in India is seeing a patient from a minority cultural and linguistic group. To foster therapeutic alliance and provide the best care possible, which of the following approaches should the physician prioritize? [INICET MAY 2022]

 

  1. Insist on good communication.
  2. Insist on communication only via an interpreter.
  3. Treat them regardless of their cultural perceptions.
  4. Consider the patient's religion and cultural perception.
questions.solution:
Ans. (d) 1, 4

 

To foster a strong therapeutic alliance and provide high-quality care, the physician should prioritize the following:

 

1. Insist on good communication: Effective communication is crucial for building a strong doctor-patient relationship. Good communication helps in understanding the patient's concerns, explaining medical conditions and treatment options clearly, and ensuring that the patient feels heard and respected.

 

4. Consider the patient's religion and cultural perception: Culturally competent care involves acknowledging and respecting the patient's cultural, religious, and linguistic background. This approach ensures that care is tailored to meet the specific needs and values of the patient, which can enhance their comfort and trust in the healthcare system.

 

Other Options:

 

2. Insist on communication only via an interpreter: Incorrect. While good communication is essential, insisting on communication only via an interpreter may not always be necessary or preferred by the patient.

 

3. Treat them regardless of their cultural perceptions: Incorrect. Treating patients regardless of their cultural perceptions does not align with providing culturally competent care, which aims to respect and incorporate cultural differences into the care plan.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • The communication skills of physicians are an effective step of making effective relationship between doctor and patient
  • Research has shown that the way patients perceive their connection with their physician significantly influences their sense of satisfaction and level of concern about their health
  • The goal of culturally competent health care services is to provide the highest quality of care to every patient, regardless of race, ethnicity, cultural background

questions.text: Which of the following activate glycogen phosphorylase? (INICET NOV 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans A) Ca2+

 

  • Explanation: Calcium ions play a role in the activation of glycogen phosphorylase. When there is a need for energy, an increase in intracellular calcium levels can activate glycogen phosphorylase. Calcium ions bind to calmodulin, which, in turn, activates phosphorylase kinase. Phosphorylase kinase then phosphorylates and activates glycogen phosphorylase.
  • Relevance: Calcium-mediated activation of glycogen phosphorylase is part of the fight-or-flight response, ensuring a rapid release of glucose for energy during periods of stress or physical activity.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Glucose 6-Phosphate:

 

  • Explanation: Glucose 6-phosphate is a product of the glycolytic pathway and is an indicator of sufficient energy within the cell. High levels of glucose 6-phosphate inhibit glycogen phosphorylase. Glycogen phosphorylase is typically activated when glucose levels are low and energy demand is high.
  • Relevance: The presence of glucose 6-phosphate signals that the cell has adequate energy reserves and does not need to break down glycogen.

 

Option C. Glucose:

 

  • Explanation: Glucose itself does not directly activate glycogen phosphorylase. In fact, high levels of glucose can have an inhibitory effect on glycogen phosphorylase because it indicates that there is sufficient glucose available for energy needs, reducing the need to break down glycogen.
  • Relevance: Elevated glucose levels signal that there is no immediate need to activate glycogen phosphorylase.

 

Option D. High ATP (Adenosine Triphosphate):

 

  • Explanation: High levels of ATP can inhibit glycogen phosphorylase. ATP is a molecule that stores energy, and when ATP levels are high, it indicates that the cell has sufficient energy reserves. In this context, glycogen phosphorylase would not be activated to break down glycogen.
  • Relevance: High ATP levels signal that there is no immediate need for additional energy from glycogenolysis.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Glycogen Phosphorylase is first and RLE of glycogenolysis. It transfers Pi, uses PLP (B6) and breaks α (1 à 4) bonds from one end until 4 glucose residues are left at branch point. End-product is Glucose 1–P (90%). It exists in two forms b and a. which is regulated by various mechanism shown as:

questions.text: Which of the following has been reported to have endemic transmission in India?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Crimean-Congo hemorrhagic fever

 

Crimean-Congo hemorrhagic fever (CCHF) is caused by the nairovirus and has been reported to have endemic transmission in India. An outbreak was identified in Gujarat in 2011, and antibodies against the virus have been found in both human and animal sera in India. CCHF is primarily transmitted by Hyalomma ticks and is associated with a high mortality rate.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Yellow fever: Yellow fever is primarily found in tropical and subtropical areas of South America and Africa and is caused by the flavivirus. It is not endemic to India. In urban settings, the disease is transmitted by Aedes aegypti mosquitoes.

 

Option C. Ebola: Ebola virus causes hemorrhagic fever and was first reported in Sudan and Zaire. It has caused several outbreaks in West Africa, but there has been no endemic transmission of Ebola in India.

 

Option D. Hendra virus: Hendra virus is primarily a zoonotic disease that affects horses and was first identified in Australia. It is not known to have any transmission in India.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Crimean-Congo hemorrhagic fever (CCHF) has endemic transmission in India, with the first outbreak reported in Gujarat in 2011. It is transmitted by Hyalomma ticks and has a high mortality rate.

questions.text: A 2 yr old child presented with fever, thrombocytopenia, hematuria. The mother tells you that the baby also suffered from diarrhea a few days back. Which is the most common organism for likely cause? (INICET NOV 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) E. Coli 0157:H7

 

The clinical presentation describes classic features of Hemolytic Uremic Syndrome (HUS), characterized by the triad of:

 

  • Hemolytic anemia 
  • Thrombocytopenia  
  • Acute kidney injury 

 

The most common causative organism for typical or diarrhea-associated HUS is Shiga toxin-producing Escherichia coli (STEC), particularly serotype O157:H7. This toxin damages endothelial cells, leading to platelet activation, microthrombi formation, and end-organ damage, particularly affecting the kidneys.

 

HUS is one of the most common causes of acute kidney injury in young children. Management focuses on supportive care, including careful fluid management, treatment of hypertension, and renal replacement therapy if needed.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Salmonella: While Salmonella can cause gastroenteritis and bacteremia, it is not typically associated with HUS. Salmonella infections commonly present with fever, diarrhea, and abdominal pain but do not typically progress to the triad of HUS.

 

Option C. Shigella: Although Shigella dysenteriae type 1 can produce Shiga toxin and cause HUS, it is much less common than E. coli O157:H7 as a cause of HUS, particularly in developed countries.

 

Option D. Yersinia: Yersinia enterocolitica can cause gastroenteritis but is not a common cause of HUS. It typically causes fever, diarrhea, and right lower quadrant pain that can mimic appendicitis.

 

Educational Objective: 

 

The clinical presentation of Hemolytic Uremic Syndrome (HUS) following diarrheal illness and identify E. coli O157:H7 as the most common causative organism.

questions.text: Egg shell calcification is seen in all the following, except? (INICET NOV 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Metastatic lymph node

 

Explanation:

 

A ring of calcification at the periphery of a lymph node is known as eggshell calcification.

 

While calcifications can occur in metastatic nodes, they usually do not form the classic eggshell pattern. Instead, calcifications in metastatic nodes are often more irregular or diffusely distributed.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Silicosis: This condition, often seen in individuals exposed to silica dust, can lead to eggshell calcification of the lymph nodes due to chronic inflammation and fibrosis.

 

Option B. Sarcoidosis: Another granulomatous disease that can lead to eggshell calcification in lymph nodes as part of its systemic manifestation affecting the lungs and lymphatic system.

 

Option C. Post-radiation therapy lymph nodes: Radiation can induce changes in lymph node structure including calcifications, commonly in a peripheral pattern, as a late sequela of treatment.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Eggshell calcification is a specific radiologic sign associated with certain granulomatous diseases and post-treatment changes but is not commonly seen in metastatic lymph nodes. It may be seen in:

 

  1. Silicosis
  2. Sarcoidosis
  3. post-radiation therapy in lymph nodes
  4. post-ATT in lymph nodes in TB

questions.text: Transport of iron into enterocytes is done by which of the following proteins: (INICET Nov 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Divalent metal transporter – 1

 

Transport of iron into enterocytes is done by divalent metal transporter-1 protein.

Iron absorption occurs in the duodenum. Iron is reduced to Fe2+ (ferrous) iron by ferrireductases and then transported across the apical membrane by divalent metal transporter 1 (DMT1).

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Transferrin: This protein binds iron in the bloodstream and transports it to various tissues, but it is not involved in the transport of iron into enterocytes.

 

Option B. Ferroportin: This protein exports iron from enterocytes into the bloodstream but does not transport iron into the cells.

 

Option C. Hepcidin: This hormone regulates iron egress from enterocytes by inhibiting ferroportin but is not involved in the transport of iron into enterocytes.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The primary transporter responsible for iron uptake into enterocytes from the intestinal lumen is the divalent metal transporter-1 (DMT1).

questions.text: A patient presents to the emergency and his ocular examination reveals the following. Which of the following is not done initially? (AIIMS May 2019)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Removal of the foreign body

 

The image shows an eye with a metallic foreign body causing a penetrating injury. In such cases, immediate removal of the foreign body is not recommended as an initial step because doing so may exacerbate the injury or lead to complications such as infection or further mechanical damage to the eye structures.

 

Other Options:

 

Proper Initial Steps Include:
 

Option B. Check for visual acuity: This helps assess the extent of damage to the eye's visual function and provides a baseline for future comparisons.

 

Option C. Give antibiotics: Prophylactic treatment to prevent infection, especially considering the risk introduced by the foreign object.

 

Option D. Do primary survey: Ensures that the patient's overall health and other potential life-threatening conditions are addressed (part of the ABCDE approach - Airway, Breathing, Circulation, Disability, Exposure).

 

Further Management:

 

CT scan: To precisely locate the foreign body and any possible penetration into the orbital or cranial cavities, helping plan for surgical intervention.

 

Avoid MRI: Due to the risk of movement of the metallic object, which can cause more damage.

 

Surgical exploration and repair in the operating theatre: To safely remove the foreign body under controlled conditions, minimizing risk of further damage.

 

Educational Objective:

 

In cases of ocular injuries involving foreign bodies, immediate removal is not advised due to the potential for further damage. Initial steps should focus on assessment, stabilization, and prevention of infection, followed by careful planning and execution of the foreign body removal under appropriate surgical conditions.

choices.text: Low mechanical fragility, high osmotic fragility
High mechanical fragility, high osmotic fragility
Low mechanical fragility, low osmotic fragility
High mechanical fragility, low osmotic fragility

questions.text: Which of the following is true about red blood cells in Sickle cell anemia: (INICET NOV 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) High mechanical fragility, low osmotic fragility

 

In sickle cell anemia, red blood cells (RBCs) have abnormal hemoglobin (HbS) that causes the cells to sickle under low oxygen conditions. These sickled cells are more prone to mechanical damage as they pass through the microcirculation, leading to increased mechanical fragility. However, their osmotic fragility is lower compared to normal RBCs because the sickling and subsequent damage to the cell membrane makes them less prone to osmotic lysis.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Sickle cells exhibit high mechanical fragility due to their abnormal shape and membrane characteristics under stress but display low osmotic fragility because they are less prone to rupture in varying osmotic conditions compared to normal red blood cells.

questions.text: In the case of a child presenting to the OPD with tense bullae over the torso, and a biopsy of the lesion revealing subepidermal blistering and neutrophil infiltration, what is the preferred drug for treatment? (INICET May 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Dapsone

 

  • A diagnosis of linear lgA disease (LIGA), or childhood chronic bullous disease is suggested by the clinical picture of tense blisters with subepidermal separation and neutrophilic infiltration at the basement membrane in a child.
  • This is an autoimmune blistering disorder that can clinically and histologically resemble bullous pemphigoid but is distinguished by linear deposits of IgA at the basement membrane zone.

 

Dapsone:

 

  • The preferred medication to treat LIGA is dapsone.
  • It typically leads to rapid clinical improvement in CBDC
  • Dapsone, which primarily kills bacteria, also has an anti-inflammatory effect by reducing neutrophil enzyme activity.
  • As a result, it is effective in the management of LIGA.
  • Other options such as rituximab, cyclosporine, and azathioprine are reserved for cases that do not respond to dapsone or when dapsone is contraindicated.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Rituximab: This is a monoclonal antibody that targets CD20 on B-cells and is used in a variety of autoimmune diseases, including those with blistering skin manifestations like pemphigus vulgaris. It is not the first-line therapy for Linear IgA disease.

 

Option C. Cyclosporine: This is an immunosuppressant that inhibits T-cell activation and is used in severe cases of many autoimmune disorders and in transplant patients. It may be used in refractory cases of Linear IgA disease but is not the first choice due to potential side effects, especially in children.

 

Option D. Azathioprine: This immunosuppressive agent is used as a steroid-sparing drug in various autoimmune conditions. It is not the first-line treatment for Linear IgA disease and is considered in cases that are refractory to dapsone.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The first-line treatment for Linear IgA disease (Chronic Bullous Disease of Childhood) is dapsone, due to its efficacy in managing conditions with neutrophilic infiltrates.

 

Ref - Fitzpatrick’s dermatology 9th edition page no 989,998

questions.text:
A 62-year-old male patient with heart failure is scheduled for a heart transplant. His renal function test is deranged, and hemoglobin is 6 g/dL. The physician ordered 2 units of whole blood. Four hours after transfusion, he developed severe respiratory distress. On examination, he is hypoxemic, has tachycardia, and his mean arterial pressure is elevated. Which of the following are the best investigations for the above scenario? (INICET NOV 2021)

 

  1. Chest X-ray
  2. Brain natriuretic peptide (BNP) level
  3. Absolute neutrophil count
  4. Leucocyte antibodies
  5. Platelets
questions.solution:
Ans. C) 1 and 2

 

The patient presents with signs and symptoms indicative of transfusion-associated circulatory overload (TACO), which includes elevated mean arterial pressure, hypoxemia, and respiratory distress following a blood transfusion. TACO occurs due to fluid overload from the transfusion, leading to pulmonary edema and increased cardiac filling pressures.

 

1. Chest X-ray: This imaging is crucial as it can reveal bilateral infiltrates indicative of pulmonary edema, a hallmark of TACO. It helps to differentiate between TACO and other causes of respiratory distress post-transfusion.

 

2. Brain Natriuretic Peptide (BNP) Level: BNP is a cardiac biomarker that is elevated in conditions of increased cardiac pressure and volume overload, such as TACO. Elevated BNP levels would support the diagnosis of TACO, whereas BNP levels would not be elevated in transfusion-related acute lung injury (TRALI), another potential complication post-transfusion that presents with respiratory distress but usually with hypotension.

 

Other Options:

 

3. Absolute neutrophil count and 5. platelets are not specific for diagnosing TACO or TRALI. These parameters do not provide information on fluid overload or cardiac stress.

 

4. Leucocyte antibodies are not directly relevant to the diagnosis of TACO. Leucocyte antibodies might be involved in TRALI, but not TACO.

 

Educational Objective:

 

For a patient with suspected transfusion-associated circulatory overload (TACO), the best investigations are a chest X-ray to detect pulmonary edema and BNP levels to assess cardiac stress and fluid overload

questions.text: As a medical student, you're learning about the margin of error and its relationship with sample size. With three studies of different sizes (Sample 1: 1000, Sample 2: 800, Sample 3: 600), how would you order the expected margins of error from largest to smallest? [AIIMS MAY 2018]
questions.solution:
Ans. (a) 3>2>1

 

  • Curve 1 exhibits the smallest margin of error, followed by Curve 2, and then Curve 3. Thus, the ranking is as follows: 3>2>1.
  • The depicted image showcases three normal distribution curves with varying sample sizes, all sharing the same mean but differing in standard deviation.
  • When the sample size decreases, the peak diminishes, and the curve adopts a flatter shape.
  • This signifies a broader confidence interval for the specified mean.
  • The width of the curve's base is directly linked to the margin of error.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • The margin of error in a study is inversely related to the square root of the sample size.
  • This relationship implies that a larger sample size will generally lead to a smaller margin of error, assuming other variables like variance remain constant.

questions.text: A patient presents to the casualty following blunt trauma to the chest. A chest X-ray was done. Among the following radiographs, in which case would you further evaluate the patient before putting a chest tube? (INICET MAY 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) 3,4

 

Explanation:

 

  1. Pneumothorax
  2. Hemothorax
  3. Consolidation
  4. Diaphragmatic hernia

 

Image 3: Consolidation would be managed symptomatically and chest tube shouldn’t be inserted.

 

Image 4: Diaphragmatic hernia: A direct blow to the diaphragm can cause it to rupture, allowing abdominal contents to herniate into the chest. In the case of stomach herniation into the chest, a nasogastric tube followed by chest radiography can be helpful. Video-assisted thoracoscopy or laparoscopy is the most accurate investigation.

 

Other Options:

 

Radiographs 1-2 show hemothorax and pneumothorax. Intercostal chest drains should be inserted into the fifth intercostal space. The safe landmark is a triangle anterior to the midaxillary line above the nipple, below, and lateral to the pectoralis major muscle.

 

Educational Objective:

 

In cases of blunt chest trauma, careful evaluation of chest radiographs is crucial. Consolidations (Image 3) and diaphragmatic hernias (Image 4) require specific management strategies distinct from those of pneumothorax or hemothorax, where immediate chest tube placement is standard.

choices.text: Reduction in the risk of ovarian cancer
Protection against sexually transmitted diseases including HIV
Reduction in the risk of endometrial cancer

questions.text: The non-contraceptive uses of oral contraceptives include all of the following except?(INICET NOV 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Protection against sexually transmitted diseases including HIV

 

Explanation:

 

The non-contraceptive benefits of combined oral contraceptive pills (COCPs) include:

 

  • Reduction in the risk of ovarian cancer: COCPs reduce the incidence of ovarian cancer.
  • Reduction in the risk of endometrial cancer: COCPs lower the incidence of endometrial malignancy.
  • Reduction in the incidence of ectopic pregnancy: COCPs decrease the likelihood of ectopic pregnancies by preventing ovulation and thickening cervical mucus.

 

However, COCPs do not provide protection against sexually transmitted diseases (STDs), including HIV.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Reduction in the risk of ovarian cancer: COCPs are known to reduce the incidence of ovarian cancer.

 

Option B. Ectopic pregnancy: COCPs lower the risk of ectopic pregnancy by preventing ovulation and thickening the cervical mucus.

 

Option D. Reduction in the risk of endometrial cancer: COCPs decrease the risk of endometrial cancer.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Combined oral contraceptive pills do not provide protection against sexually transmitted diseases (STDs), including HIV.

 

Ref: William’s textbook of gynecology 3rd edition pg 124, Dutta’s textbook of gynecology 6th edition pg 489

questions.text: The blood supply to the structure marked in the image is by? (AIIMS Nov 2019)
questions.solution:
Ans. C. Anterior cerebral artery

 

Explanation:

 

The marked structure is fornix which is supplied by the anterior cerebral artery.

 

The optic chiasma, lamina terminalis, hypothalamus, para-olfactory regions, and cingulate gyrus are all supplied by the anteromedial central branches of the anterior cerebral artery in addition to the fornix.

 

The fornix is a C-shaped bundle of nerve fibers in the brain that plays a crucial role in memory and cognitive functions. It is supplied by

 

  1. Anterior Cerebral Artery (ACA): The ACA is one of the major arteries of the Circle of Willis and is responsible for supplying blood to the frontal lobes of the brain, including the anterior part of the fornix.
  2. Posterior Cerebral Artery (PCA): The PCA is another major artery of the Circle of Willis, and its branches supply blood to the posterior part of the fornix.
  3. Anterior Choroidal Artery: This artery arises from the internal carotid artery and supplies blood to the choroid plexus in the lateral and third ventricles of the brain. It also sends branches to the fornix, particularly the inferior part.
  4. Septal Branches: The fornix also receives blood supply from septal branches, which originate from the anterior cerebral arteries. Top of Form

 

Educational Objective:
