choices.text: No intervention as the patient is asymptomatic

questions.text: A 45-year-old woman is found to have a fibroid of 14 weeks size. She has no specific symptoms. What is the next step in management? (INICET NOV 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) No intervention as the patient is asymptomatic

 

Explanation:

 

In the case of an asymptomatic fibroid, intervention is generally not required regardless of the size. The management approach is typically conservative, involving observation and regular monitoring.

 

Key Points:

 

  • Asymptomatic Fibroids: Fibroids that do not cause symptoms do not require immediate intervention. Instead, they can be observed with yearly ultrasounds or reviewed earlier if symptoms develop.
  • Common Symptoms of Fibroids: These include heavy menstrual bleeding, dysmenorrhea, pressure symptoms, and the presence of an abdominal mass.
  • Management of Symptomatic Fibroids: Depending on the patient's age, size of the fibroid, number, and location, symptomatic fibroids may be considered for myomectomy or hysterectomy.

 

Other options:

 

Option A. Hysterectomy: This is a major surgical procedure and is typically reserved for symptomatic fibroids or when other treatment options have failed or are not suitable.

 

Option B. Myomectomy: Myomectomy is a surgical procedure to remove fibroids and is considered for symptomatic patients who wish to preserve their uterus.

 

Option D. Medical management: Medical management is used to manage symptoms and is not necessary for asymptomatic fibroids.

 

Educational Objective:

 

In asymptomatic patients with fibroids, intervention is generally not required. Observation and regular monitoring are appropriate unless symptoms develop, in which case, further management options such as myomectomy or hysterectomy may be considered.

 

Ref: Williams Textbook of gynecology 3rdedition Pg207

choices.text: Visible peristalsis from left to right

questions.text: A child is diagnosed with congenital hypertrophic pyloric stenosis, which among the following will not be seen in this child? (AIIMS NOV 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Bilious vomiting

 

In congenital hypertrophic pyloric stenosis, the hypertrophy and hyperplasia of the pylorus muscle lead to gastric outlet obstruction. This causes projectile, non-bilious vomiting because the obstruction is proximal to the bile duct entry into the duodenum.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Visible peristalsis from left to right: Due to the obstruction caused by CHPS, there's an increase in gastric peristalsis as the stomach tries to push its contents past the hypertrophied pylorus. This can result in visible waves of peristalsis moving from the left side of the abdomen (where the stomach is located) to the right side (towards the pylorus) on giving a feed.

 

Option C. Hypochloremia and hypokalemia: Persistent vomiting in CHPS can lead to the loss of gastric acid (hydrochloric acid). This results in hypochloremia due to the loss of chloride ions. The body also tries to compensate for the alkalosis by excreting more potassium in the kidneys, leading to hypokalemia.

 

Option D. Metabolic alkalosis: As mentioned earlier, the loss of gastric acid from repeated vomiting results in a state of metabolic alkalosis.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • CHPS (congenital hypertrophic pyloric stenosis) is most commonly seen in infants between 2 to 8 weeks of age.
  • It is caused by the hypertrophy of the circular muscle of the Pylorus, which results in constriction and obstruction of the gastric outlet.
  • First-born male infants are at the highest risk for developing CHPS.
  • Projectile, non-bilious vomiting is a common symptom in infants with CHPS.
  • A palpable olive-shaped mass is usually felt in the right upper quadrant or epigastrium, and visible peristalsis can be observed moving from left to right, followed by projectile vomiting.
  • Infants with CHPS develop a characteristic metabolic abnormality including hypokalemic hypochloremic metabolic alkalosis with paradoxical aciduria.
  • Loss of hydrochloric acid leads to metabolic alkalosis and hypochloremia due to persistent vomiting.
  • The kidneys try to compensate for alkalosis by secreting Na+ and HCO3, but the loss of sodium stimulates aldosterone secretion leading to the loss of potassium ions (hypokalemia).
  • Loss of H+ ions in urine lowers the urinary pH resulting in paradoxical aciduria.
  • Treatment involves rehydration and correction of metabolic abnormalities before surgery, and the Ramstedt pyloromyotomy is the standard surgical procedure for CHPS.

questions.text: What event takes place when the retina is exposed to light? (INICET Nov 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Hyperpolarization, decrease in neurotransmitter release

 

The retina responds to light by initiating a process called phototransduction, which converts light energy into an electrical signal. This process involves the activation of rods and cones, which are the photoreceptor cells in the retina.

 

In the dark, the cGMP gated channels in the photoreceptor cells are open, allowing a steady release of neurotransmitters such as glutamate. However, when light falls on the retina, a series of biochemical reactions occur, leading to the conversion of 11-cis-retinal to all-trans-retinal. This process activates transducin, which is a G protein-coupled receptor with phosphodiesterase activity, resulting in the breakdown of cGMP. As a result of the decrease in cGMP levels, sodium channels close, causing hyperpolarization of the photoreceptor cell.

 

The hyperpolarization leads to a decrease in glutamate release, which ultimately triggers the formation of an action potential. This process enables the transmission of visual information from the photoreceptor cells to the brain, allowing us to perceive and interpret visual images.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Hyperpolarization, increase in neurotransmitter release: This is incorrect because hyperpolarization of photoreceptor cells leads to a decrease, not an increase, in neurotransmitter release.

 

Option C. Depolarization, decrease in neurotransmitter release: This is incorrect because light exposure causes hyperpolarization, not depolarization, of photoreceptor cells.

 

Option D. Depolarization, increase in neurotransmitter release: This is also incorrect as it suggests the opposite response of photoreceptors to light. Depolarization and increased neurotransmitter release occur in the absence of light (i.e., in the dark).

 

Educational Objective:

 

Light exposure results in the hyperpolarization of photoreceptor cells in the retina, leading to a decrease in the release of the neurotransmitter glutamate. This process is crucial for converting light signals into electrical signals that can be processed by the brain to form visual images.

questions.text: A bodybuilder starts eating raw eggs for protein. He starts to develop fatigue on moderate exercise. The doctor prescribes a vitamin. Which enzyme is deficient in him? (AIIMS May 2019)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Pyruvate Carboxylase

 

Raw eggs contain a protein called avidin, which binds to biotin and prevents its absorption in the intestine. Biotin is a vital coenzyme for several carboxylase enzymes, including pyruvate carboxylase. When biotin is deficient, these enzymes cannot function properly, leading to symptoms such as fatigue, particularly during moderate exercise.

 

Mechanism:

  • Avidin in Raw Eggs: Binds strongly to biotin, preventing its absorption and leading to biotin deficiency.
  • Pyruvate Carboxylase Deficiency: Results in impaired gluconeogenesis and energy production, causing fatigue during exercise.

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Glucose 6 Phosphate:

  • Function: Involved in glycogenolysis and the pentose phosphate pathway.
  • Relevance: Not related to biotin deficiency or the symptoms described.

 

Option C. PEPCK (Phosphoenolpyruvate Carboxykinase):

  • Function: Catalyzes the conversion of oxaloacetate to phosphoenolpyruvate in gluconeogenesis.
  • Relevance: Although involved in gluconeogenesis, its activity is not directly dependent on biotin.

 

Option D. Glycogen Phosphorylase:

  • Function: Breaks down glycogen to glucose-1-phosphate in glycogenolysis.
  • Relevance: Not related to biotin deficiency or the symptoms described.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Eating raw eggs can lead to biotin deficiency due to avidin binding, resulting in a deficiency of pyruvate carboxylase. This enzyme deficiency impairs gluconeogenesis, causing fatigue during exercise. Supplementing biotin can correct the deficiency and alleviate symptoms.

questions.text:
Which of the following is a suicide inhibitor?  (INICET May 2024)

 

  1. Nor-ethindrone
  2. Ritonavir
  3. Spironolactone
  4. Benzbromarone
questions.solution:
Ans. A) 1, 2 and 3

 

A suicide inhibitor (also known as a mechanism-based inhibitor) is a type of enzyme inhibitor that binds to an enzyme and undergoes a catalytic reaction, leading to the formation of an irreversible complex. During this reaction, the inhibitor is converted into a reactive form by the enzyme itself, which then covalently binds to the enzyme, permanently inactivating it. In essence, the enzyme “commits suicide” by converting the inhibitor into a form that irreversibly binds to it, thereby blocking the enzyme's activity permanently.

 

Among the given options, nor-ethindrone, ritonavir and spironolactone are suicide inhibitors whereas benzbromarone is not. 

 

  1. Nor-ethindrone: Nor-ethindrone is a synthetic progestin that is commonly used in hormonal contraceptives. It is also classified as a suicide inhibitor due to its irreversible binding to its target enzyme, leading to permanent inhibition of enzyme activity.
  2. Ritonavir: Ritonavir is an HIV protease inhibitor that acts as a suicide inhibitor. It binds irreversibly to the HIV protease enzyme, permanently inactivating it.
  3. Spironolactone: Spironolactone is a potassium-sparing diuretic and aldosterone antagonist. It is also categorized as a suicide inhibitor because it irreversibly inhibits the 17α-hydroxylase enzyme involved in steroid synthesis.
  4. Benzbromarone: Benzbromarone is a uricosuric drug used to treat gout by increasing the renal excretion of uric acid. However, it is not classified as a suicide inhibitor. While it has therapeutic uses, it does not act by irreversibly inactivating enzymes like suicide inhibitors do.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Suicide inhibitors, also known as mechanism-based inhibitors, irreversibly bind to and permanently inactivate their target enzymes. This type of inhibition is significant because the enzyme activity cannot be restored unless new enzymes are synthesized by the body.

 

Mnemonic to Remember Important Suicide Inhibitors:

 

“Every Nurse Sees The Clot Results Promptly”

 

  • E: Ethinyl estradiol
  • N: Norethindrone
  • S: Spironolactone
  • T: Ticlopidine
  • C: Clopidogrel
  • R: Ritonavir
  • P: Propylthiouracil

questions.text: Mr. Thompson, a 58-year-old male, underwent laparoscopic cholecystectomy for the treatment of gallstones. Following the procedure, he complained of abdominal pain and fever. Upon further evaluation, it was found that he had a bile leak. The surgeon ordered imaging tests to identify the extent of the bile duct injury. The imaging results showed injury to the right aberrant posterior sectoral duct with bile leak. What would be the Strasberg classification of this injury? (AIIMS NOV 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Type C

 

Injury to the right aberrant posterior sectoral duct associated with bile leak is classified as Strasberg's type C injury.

 

Correct. Strasberg Type C injuries are defined by bile leaks from the major ductal systems, such as the right posterior sectoral duct in this case. The leak can be caused by a missed stone, an unrecognized transection, or an avulsion due to excessive traction.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Type A: Strasberg Type A injuries are characterized by bile leaks from minor ducts or cystic duct that are present either at or near the gallbladder bed. They often present as bile collections in the gallbladder fossa.

 

Option B. Type B: Type B injuries involve an occlusion of the right posterior bile duct. This occlusion might be due to a clip placement or ligature, typically at the time of surgery. It does not involve a bile leak from an aberrant right posterior sectoral duct.

 

Option D. Type D: Type D injuries are characterized by lateral injury or partial transection of extrahepatic bile ducts/Common hepatic hepatic. This would be more extensive than just a leak from an aberrant duct.

 

Educational Objective:

questions.text: Which of the following is not a cytochrome C oxidase inhibitor? (INICET NOV 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Nitric oxide


Nitric oxide is not an inhibitor of cytochrome C oxidase (complex IV of electron transport chain). NO (nitric oxide) is synthesized from arginine by the enzyme NO synthase and causes vasodilation. It has a role in physiological processes like erection and is inhibited by smoking, which can lead to erectile dysfunction.

 

Inhibitors of ETC Complexes

 

 

Other Options:


Option A. Carbon monoxide: This is an inhibitor of cytochrome C oxidase (complex IV). Carbon monoxide is part of the mnemonic "i'd" which includes carbon monoxide, cyanide, hydrogen sulfide, and sodium azide as inhibitors of complex IV.

 

Option C. Hydrogen sulfide: This is an inhibitor of cytochrome C oxidase (complex IV). Hydrogen sulfide is listed among the substances that inhibit cytochrome C oxidase.

 

Option D. Cyanide: This is an inhibitor of cytochrome C oxidase (complex IV). Cyanide is included in the list of substances that inhibit cytochrome C oxidase.

 

Educational Objective:


Nitric oxide (NO) is not an inhibitor of cytochrome C oxidase (complex IV), while carbon monoxide, hydrogen sulfide, and cyanide are inhibitors of this complex IV  in the electron transport chain.

questions.text: The vector shown in the image below transmits which of the following organism? [INICET MAY 2023]
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Orientia tsutsugamushi

 

  • The picture depicts a trombiculid mite, known for transmitting Orientia tsutsugamushi.

 

SCRUB TYPHUS (ORIENTIA)

 

  • Caused by → Orientia tsutsugamushi
  • Vector → Trombiculid mites (Leptotrombidium)
  • Chiggerosis → Among all stages of mite, larvae (called chiggers) are only stage that feed on humans. Hence, scrub typhus is also called chiggerosis.
  • Clinical manifestations
    • Eschar (at the site of bite)
    • Regional lymphadenopathy
    • Maculopapular rash
  • DOC → Doxycycline

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Kyasanur forest disease: Kyasanur forest disease is vector borne disease caused by hard tick.

 

 

Option C. Chandipura virus: Chandipura virus is vector borne disease transmitted by sandfly

 

 

Option D. Anaplasma: Anaplasma is a tick-borne disease affecting ruminants, dogs, and horses, and is caused by Anaplasma bacteria. Mainly transmitted by Ixodes ticks.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • The trombiculid mite, particularly in its larval stage called a chigger, transmits Orientia tsutsugamushi, the causative agent of scrub typhus.

questions.text: A patient presents at 36 weeks with chronic HTN and 3+ proteinuria. Her BP is 170/100 mmHg and she complains of headache and blurring of vision. What is the best management option? (INICET MAY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Labetalol + MgSO4 + Expedite delivery

 

This patient is presenting with chronic hypertension that has progressed to superimposed preeclampsia, indicated by the development of 3+ proteinuria, a blood pressure of 170/100 mmHg, and symptoms such as headache and blurring of vision. These symptoms and her elevated blood pressure suggest severe preeclampsia.

 

  • Severe Preeclampsia: A systolic blood pressure greater than 160 mmHg or a diastolic blood pressure greater than 110 mmHg, along with symptoms like headache and visual disturbances, are indicators of severe preeclampsia. In this case, the patient’s condition requires urgent management to prevent the development of eclampsia, a condition that can lead to seizures and other severe complications.
  • Management: The correct management for severe preeclampsia at 36 weeks gestation includes the administration of Labetalol to lower the blood pressure, Magnesium sulfate (MgSO4) to prevent seizures, and expedited delivery to resolve the preeclampsia. After 34 weeks of gestation, delivery is recommended for severe preeclampsia because the risks of continuing the pregnancy outweigh the benefits.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Labetalol + MgSO4 + Wait till 37 weeks: As this is severe preeclampsia, there is a very high risk waiting till 37 weeks. Immediate delivery is indicated after 34 weeks

 

Option C. Labetalol + Corticosteroids + wait till 37 weeks: There is no indication for corticosteroids as she has crossed 34 weeks and also there is no indication to wait till 37 weeks as this is severe preeclampsia

 

Option D. Labetalol + Corticosteroids + Expedite delivery: Although delivery needs to be expedited, there is no indication for corticosteroids as she has crossed 34 weeks.

 

Educational Objective:

 

In cases of severe preeclampsia after 34 weeks, immediate delivery, blood pressure control with labetalol, and seizure prophylaxis with magnesium sulfate are essential for optimal maternal and fetal outcomes.

questions.text:
Which of the following cells are present in the molecular layer of the cerebellum?(INICET MAY 2022)

 

1. Stellate cells

2. Basket cells

3. Purkinje cells

4. Granular cells
questions.solution:
Ans. A. 1, 2

 

The molecular layer of the cerebellum contains stellate and basket cells.

 

The molecular layer is one of the three layers of the cerebellar cortex, along with the granular layer and the Purkinje cell layer. It is involved in the processing of sensory information, as well as motor planning and coordination. The stellate and basket cells within the molecular layer provide inhibitory feedback to the Purkinje cells, which are the only output neurons of the cerebellar cortex.

 

The parallel fibres, which originate from granule cells in the granular layer, run perpendicular to the Purkinje cell dendrites and provide excitatory input to the molecular layer. As the parallel fibres traverse the molecular layer, they make multiple synapses with the dendrites of Purkinje cells, where inhibitory synapses are formed. This allows the Purkinje cells to integrate the incoming excitatory and inhibitory signals and adjust their output accordingly.

 

Overall, the molecular layer plays a crucial role in the cerebellar circuitry and contributes to the precision of motor movements and balance.

 

 

1. Stellate cells:

  • Location: Stellate cells are present in the molecular layer of the cerebellum.
  • Function: These are inhibitory interneurons that primarily release GABA (gamma-aminobutyric acid) and inhibit the dendrites of Purkinje cells.
     

2. Basket cells:

  • Location: Basket cells are also located in the molecular layer of the cerebellum.
  • Function: These are another type of inhibitory interneuron. The axons of basket cells form "baskets" around the cell bodies of Purkinje cells, releasing GABA and inhibiting them.

 

Other Options:

 

3. Purkinje cells:

  • Location: Purkinje cells form their own distinct layer known as the Purkinje cell layer, which is situated between the molecular layer and the granular layer.
  • Function: These cells are the primary output neurons of the cerebellar cortex. They have large, flattened dendritic trees that extend into the molecular layer, receiving inputs from climbing fibers and parallel fibers. The axons of Purkinje cells send inhibitory projections to the cerebellar nuclei.
     

4. Granular cells:

  • Location: Granular cells are present in the granular layer, which is the innermost layer of the cerebellar cortex.
  • Function: These cells receive inputs from mossy fibers, which originate from various brainstem nuclei and the spinal cord. Granular cells send their axons into the molecular layer, where they bifurcate to form parallel fibers. These parallel fibers synapse onto the dendrites of Purkinje cells.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The molecular layer of the cerebellum primarily contains stellate and basket cells. This layer is one of three distinct layers of the cerebellar cortex and is crucial for integrating sensory and motor information to refine motor coordination and balance.

questions.text:
Consider the following Statements? [INICET NOV 2023]

 

  • Statement 1- Contemplation – A person who smokes is thinking of quitting smoking
  • Statement 2- Precontemplation – A person is considering starting morning walks and its benefits to the health
  • Statement 3- Maintenance phase/determination phase – A person quit smoking one year back and has not smoked since then
  • Statement 4- Action phase – A person with obesity says he cant’s do anything as it runs deep in his family
questions.solution:
Ans. (a) Statement 1 and 3 are correct

 

1. Contemplation: A person who smokes is thinking of quitting smoking. This statement correctly aligns with the contemplation phase where an individual acknowledges the problem and begins to think seriously about solving it soon but hasn’t committed to action yet.

 

3. Maintenance phase/determination phase: A person quit smoking one year back and has not smoked since then. This is an accurate description of the maintenance phase, where the individual has made significant changes and is focused on maintaining these changes long-term. The use of "determination phase" here is non-standard; typically, it is just called "maintenance.

 

Other Options:

 

2. Precontemplation: A person is considering starting morning walks and its benefits to the health. This statement is incorrect for this phase. The precontemplation phase is characterized by a lack of awareness or denial of the problem, not considering changes. The correct description would be not considering the benefits or need for exercise.

 

4. Action phase: A person with obesity says he can't do anything as it runs deep in his family. This statement incorrectly describes the action phase. The action phase involves active modification of behavior. This description instead suggests resignation or justification for inaction, which could fit the precontemplation or contemplation phase but is misaligned with the proactive nature of the action phase.

 

Educational Objective :

 

Behavior change – 6 stages –

 

Precontemplation → Contemplation → Preparation/ Determination → Action/will power → Maintenance → Termination

questions.text: Which of the following is a component of the neuromuscular criteria for maturity according to the expanded New Ballard score? (AIIMS MAY 2019)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Scarf sign

 

The extended new Ballard score has a component of scarf sign which is a component of the neuromuscular maturity. The New Ballard Score is an extended to include extremely pre-term babies i.e. up to 20 weeks.

 

The scoring relies on the intra-uterine changes that the fetus undergoes during its maturation. Whereas the neurological criteria depend mainly upon muscle tone, the physical ones rely on anatomical changes. The neonate (less than 37 weeks of age) is in a state of physiological hypotonia. This tone increases throughout the fetal growth period, meaning a more premature baby would have lesser muscle tone.

 

Scarf sign: If the infant's arm is pulled medially across the chest (as shown in the image below)

 

 

  • In a hypotonic infant, the elbow will cross the midline.
  • In a term infant with a normal tone, the elbow will not reach the midline.

 

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Heel-knee test: Heel to knee test is not a part of ballard score

 

Option B. Finger-nose test: Finger to nose test is done to assess the cerebellar function.

 

Option D. Cubital angle: The cubital angle, also known as the carrying angle, is measured during the Services Selection Board (SSB) testing process. This has no role in ballard score.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The extended new Ballard score has a component of scarf sign which is a component of the neuromuscular maturity

questions.text:
Sequentially arrange the following renal injuries from least severe to most severe. 

 

  1. Subcapsular hematoma
  2. Injury confined to Gerota’s fascia
  3. Avulsion of Pelvi-ureteric junction
  4. Shattered kidney
questions.solution:
Ans. D) 1, 2, 3, 4


The correct sequence from least to most severe renal injuries is as follows:

 

  1. Subcapsular hematoma (Grade I): A non-expanding hematoma under the capsule without parenchymal laceration.
  2. Injury confined to Gerota’s fascia (Grade II): Hematoma confined within the renal fascia without significant renal tissue damage.
  3. Avulsion of Pelvi-ureteric junction (Grade IV): Injury involving avulsion of the renal pelvis or ureter, often associated with significant bleeding.
  4. Shattered kidney (Grade V): Represents a severe renal injury with extensive fragmentation or laceration of the renal tissue.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The American Association for the Surgery of Trauma (AAST) grading helps assess the severity of renal injuries, and CT scans are typically used for evaluating these injuries in trauma cases.

choices.text: Elevated B-hCG, PAPP-A and lower estriol, AFP
Elevated B-hCG, Inhibin and lower estriol, AFP
Lower -CG, PAPP-A and elevated estriol, AFP
Lower B-hCG, Inhibin and elevated estriol, AFP

questions.text: Which of the following changes can be seen in the quadruple screening for Down syndrome? (INICET MAY 2018)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Elevated B-hCG, Inhibin and lower estriol, AFP

 

The triple and quadruple test is done between 15 – 21 weeks.

 

  • Components of Triple test are: Free β hCG, unconjugated Estriol (uE3) and Maternal Serum α-fetoprotein.
  • Components of the Quadruple test are: Free β hCG, unconjugated Estriol (uE3), Maternal Serum α-fetoprotein. And Inhibin A.

 

 

Easy to remember: B for Big; so in Down’s syndrome; Beta hCG and InhiBin A: Big/ Increased

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Elevated B-hCG, PAPP-A and lower estriol, AFP: This combination is not correct as PAPP-A is not part of the quadruple test and it typically decreases in Down syndrome.

 

Option C. Lower B-hCG, PAPP-A and elevated estriol, AFP: This combination is not correct for Down syndrome. β hCG and Inhibin A are elevated in Down syndrome.

 

Option D. Lower B-hCG, Inhibin and elevated estriol, AFP: This combination is not correct for Down syndrome. β hCG and Inhibin A are elevated in Down syndrome.

 

Educational Objective:

 

In Down syndrome (Trisomy 21), the quadruple test shows elevated β hCG and Inhibin A, and decreased AFP and uE3.

 

Ref: Page no 863, Williams Obstetrics 26th edition

questions.text: A patient came to hospital who has not eaten anything for 2 days. Which of the following tests will be positive?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Only 3

 

Explanation:

 

Prolonged fasting leads to ketonuria which can be detected by Rothera’s test i.e., test 3

 

Rothera's test: Saturate 5 mL of urine with solid ammonium sulphate. Add a few drops of freshly prepared sodium nitroprusside followed by 2 mL of liquor ammonia along the sides of the test tube. Development of a purple ring indicates the presence of ketone bodies in urine. Strip tests based on the same principle are also available.

 

Other tests

 

Test 1: Benedict’s test: To 5 mL Benedict’s reagent, add 0.5 mL urine. Boil for 2 minutes. Blue, green, yellow, orange or red precipitate indicate reducing sugars. Black colour (muddy brown) is seen if homogentisic acid is present. Disaccharides may be identified by alkali destruction test. As there is low glucose in blood and will not be excreted in urine. So It will be negative.

 

The urine of a patient with diabetic keto acidosis will give positive Benedict's test as well as Rothera's test. But in starvation ketosis, Benedict's test is negative, but Rothera's test will be positive.

 

Test 2: Shows the heat coagulation test. The heat coagulation test is used to detect the presence of proteins in urine. Since proteins are generally conserved during fasting to protect muscle mass, this test will be negative, rather proteins will be conserved to protect muscles.

 

Educational Objective

 

Prolonged fasting leads to ketosis, which can be detected by Rothera’s test (test 3), resulting in a positive result for ketone bodies in the urine.

questions.text: A patient presented with chronic diarrhea and steatorrhea. D-xylose test was normal and the Schilling test was abnormal. A duodenal biopsy was normal. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Pancreatic insufficiency

 

The presentation of chronic diarrhea and steatorrhea indicates a malabsorption syndrome. Key diagnostic tests include the D-xylose test, duodenal biopsy, and Schilling test to help identify the underlying pathology. In this case:

 

  1. Normal D-xylose test – This suggests an intact small intestinal mucosa, as D-xylose is a monosaccharide absorbed directly by the intestinal lining without requiring digestive enzymes.
  2. Normal duodenal biopsy – This finding further excludes small intestinal conditions like celiac disease or intestinal lymphangiectasia, which typically show abnormalities on biopsy.
  3. Abnormal Schilling test – An abnormal Schilling test indicates impaired absorption of vitamin B12. Pancreatic enzymes are required to release vitamin B12 from its bound form, facilitating its absorption. In pancreatic insufficiency, a lack of these enzymes leads to an abnormal Schilling test, which may normalize after pancreatic enzyme supplementation.

 

Pancreatic insufficiency, often associated with chronic pancreatitis, causes a deficiency in pancreatic enzymes, which are crucial for the digestion and absorption of nutrients, particularly fats. This deficiency leads to steatorrhea and an abnormal Schilling test, aligning with the clinical findings.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Celiac disease:  In celiac disease, the D-xylose test would typically be decreased, and duodenal biopsy would show abnormal findings such as villous atrophy, crypt hyperplasia, and epithelial cell damage. This makes celiac disease an unlikely diagnosis here.

 

Option B. Ulcerative colitis:  Ulcerative colitis affects the colon and does not typically lead to fat malabsorption or steatorrhea, as fat absorption occurs in the small intestine. Additionally, it does not affect the Schilling or D-xylose tests.

 

Option C. Intestinal lymphangiectasia : This condition involves abnormal lymphatic function, leading to malabsorption, but it would show an abnormal duodenal biopsy with findings such as dilated lymphatics and clubbed villi. The normal biopsy here rules out this diagnosis.

 

Educational Objective:

questions.text: The catalytic efficiency of enzyme is best expressed by which of the following kinetic constants? (AIIMS May 2019)
questions.solution:
Ans. A. Kcat/Km

 

The catalytic efficiency is the ratio of Kcat/Km.

 

Kcat is the first-order rate constant that determines the reaction rate when the enzyme is fully occupied at a saturating concentration of the substrate.

 

The Michaelis constant (Km), defined as the concentration of substrate that is transported at half the maximal velocity (Vmax) of transport, is a measure of the affinity of the transporter for its substrate.

 

Decreasing the catalytic efficiency or the quantity of the catalyst for the "bottleneck" or rate-limiting reaction therefore reduces metabolite flux through the entire pathway. Conversely, an increase in either its quantity or catalytic efficiency enhances flux through the pathway as a whole.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The catalytic efficiency of an enzyme is best expressed by the ratio Kcat/Km, as it provides a measure of how effectively the enzyme converts substrate into product, considering both the enzyme's turnover rate and its substrate affinity.

choices.text: To find out the axis in astigmatism

questions.text: You can use a stenopaeic slit for all of the following except? (AIIMS Nov 2018)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Corneal tattooing

 

Stenopaeic slit is not used in corneal tattooing.

 

Corneal tattooing was introduced as an attempt to mask the leukomatous opacities of the eye during ancient times. Corneal tattooing is also found to reduce glare within the eye due to iris loss and increase visual acuity.

 

Many different types of inks are used throughout history and today for the dyeing of the cornea. Today, India ink is the most commonly used, providing safe and long-lasting effects, but other dyes include metallic colors in powder form, various organic dyes, and uveal pigment from animal eyes.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Fincham's test: Used specifically to evaluate differences in the nature of halos seen by patients, aiding in the differential diagnosis between cataract and glaucoma.

 

Option C. Optical Iridectomy: The stenopaeic slit assists in locating the best area on the cornea for performing an iridectomy, essential in cases where peripheral vision needs to be preserved.

 

Option D. To find out the axis in astigmatism: It is instrumental in determining the precise axis for corrective lenses, which is vital for proper astigmatism management.

 

STENOPAEIC SLIT

 

 

Educational Objective:

 

Uses of stenopaeic slit test:

 

  • Fincham's test: to differentiate between the colored halos due to cataract and corneal edema due to glaucoma.
  • To find out the optimal site for optical iridectomy in case of corneal opacities.
  • To find out the axis in astigmatism.

choices.text: Diet should contain 400 kcal from carbohydrates
Diet should contain 800 kcal from fat

questions.text: What does the FDA say about a diet, high in fat intake? [INICET MAY 2023]
questions.solution:
Ans. (b) Diet should contain total 1000 kcal

 

  • According to FDA, high fat diet is a diet having 50% of total caloric content of the meal and a high calorie diet is a diet containing total 1000 kcal.
  • This meal should derive approximately 150, 250, and 500-600 calories from protein, carbohydrate, and fat, respectively

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Diet should contain 400 kcal from carbohydrates: Incorrect. While carbohydrates are a part of the diet, this specific statement does not match the FDA's guideline for a high-fat diet.

 

Option C. Diet should contain 800 kcal from fat: Incorrect. A high-fat diet typically derives around 500-600 kcal from fat, not 800 kcal.

 

Option D. Diet should contain 80% fats: Incorrect. A high-fat diet is defined by having around 50% of its caloric content from fats, not 80%.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • The FDA defines a high-fat diet as one that has around 50% of its total caloric intake from fats, and a high-calorie diet should contain a total of 1000 kcal.

questions.text: A patient presented with a history of minor trauma 20 days back with a piece of wood. He presented as shown in the image. CT scan revealed clear sinuses and the presence of subcutaneous nodules. Microscopy of the tissue sections are positive to PAS and positive on Gomori methamine silver stain. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Phycomycosis

 

The given clinical scenario points to a diagnosis of Phycomycosis /Mucormycosis.

 

It is fungal infection of nose and paranasal sinuses which may prove rapidly fatal. It is seen in uncontrolled diabetics or in those taking immunosuppressive drugs.

 

PATHOLOGY – From the nose and sinuses, infection can spread to orbit, cribriform plate, meninges and brain. The rapid destruction associated with the disease is due to affinity of the fungus to invade the arteries and cause endothelial damage and thrombosis.

 

CLINICAL FEATURES – Black necrotic mass filling the nasal cavity and eroding the septum and hard palate.

 

DIAGNOSIS – Special stains help to identify the fungus in tissue sections.

 

Black turbinate sign is seen on contrast MRI.

 

TREATMENT – Amphotericin B and surgical debridement of the affected tissues and control of underlying predisposing cause.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Midline lethal granuloma: Primarily involves destructive lesions of the midline facial structures but lacks the fungal component.

 

Option B. Foreign body granuloma: Typically arises from a reaction to a foreign material but would not cause the extensive symptoms or be positive on the fungal stains used.

 

Option D. IgG4 granuloma: Associated with elevated levels of IgG4 and typically presents with tumefactive lesions, not primarily infectious.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Phycomycosis is a serious fungal infection affecting mainly the nasal passages and sinuses, identifiable by special staining techniques and known for its aggressive, potentially fatal progression requiring prompt treatment with antifungals and surgery.

questions.text: A school going child had applied henna and comes to dermatology OPD with the following lesions What is the possible diagnosis? (INICET Nov 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Dermatitis artefacta

 

The given image points towards a likely diagnosis of dermatitis Artefacta.

 

  • Dermatitis artefacta is a psychodermatological disorder where lesions are self-inflicted, often due to psychological stress or disorders. The pattern of the lesions, which are well-circumscribed and may follow an accessible pattern that the child could reach, is suggestive of dermatitis artefacta.
  • Dermatitis artefacta is a condition in which the patient deliberately produces skin lesions without any rational motive. This is a psychological ailment where the patient is fully aware of their actions.

 

Diagnosis:

 

  • Indicated by the symmetrical placement of lesions in accessible areas on the face, neck, chest etc. Additionally, the lesions may exhibit varying stages of healing, similar to an abrasion.
  • These visible symptoms of dermatitis artefacta can be seen as a form of nonverbal communication, representing a "cry for attention and help" from a patient who is unable to express their needs through meaningful verbal communication.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Contact dermatitis due to henna:

 

  • Contact dermatitis from henna, often related to the chemical para-phenylenediamine (PPD), usually manifests as a diffuse, erythematous rash in areas where the henna was applied.
  • If the reaction were due to henna, one would expect to see an affected scalp where the henna was applied.
  • However, the presence of localized lesions on the cheek and the normal appearance of the scalp suggests that this is not a case of allergic contact dermatitis (ACD) caused by henna.

 

Option C. Polymorphic light eruption (PLE):

 

  • This is an abnormal reaction to sunlight it is not expected to have a direct correlation with the application of henna.
  • Lesions will be small, itchy papules or Papulo-vesicles on an erythematous background. They will also be monomorphic (unlike as the name suggests).

 

Option D. Vitiligo:

 

  • Vitiligo is characterized by depigmentation of the skin and would not present with erythematous or inflamed lesions as shown in the image.
  • It represents a loss of pigment and is not physically raised or inflamed.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • In assessing skin lesions, it's important to consider the psychological aspect of dermatology.
  • Dermatitis artefacta should be suspected in lesions that are localized, well-circumscribed, and do not have a distribution pattern consistent with the history or other physical causes.

 

Ref:

Rooks’ textbook of dermatology 9th edition 128.13

Kaplan & Saddocks concise textbook of clinical Psychiatry 11th edition page 435, 436

Fitzpatrick’s dermatology 9th edition 405

choices.text: Oxidative decarboxylation of alpha-ketoglutarate is increased.
﻿﻿﻿Increased synthesis of glutamine and glutamate from alpha-ketoglutarate

questions.text: Which of the following is false in a patient with advanced liver disease?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Oxidative decarboxylation of alpha-ketoglutarate

 

“Oxidative decarboxylation of alpha-ketoglutarate is increased is false. 

 

This process occurs in the TCA (Krebs) cycle and is catalyzed by alpha-ketoglutarate dehydrogenase, a mitochondrial enzyme.


In advanced liver disease, alpha-ketoglutarate is diverted toward glutamate and glutamine synthesis (to help detoxify ammonia), which decreases its availability for the TCA cycle.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Increased synthesis of glutamine and glutamate from alpha-ketoglutarate is true. In liver disease, there is an increased synthesis of glutamine and glutamate as a way to detoxify ammonia. 

 

Option C. Decreased ATP synthesis is true. in advanced liver disease, ammonia levels increase which withdraws α-ketoglutarate to form glutamate and glutamine. This in turn results in lowered concentrations of citric acid cycle intermediates, and hence decreased ATP synthesis.

 

Option D. Hyperammonemia is true. In advanced liver disease, the liver's ability to detoxify ammonia is compromised, leading to elevated ammonia levels in the bloodstream, resulting in hyperammonemia.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Detoxification of ammonia takes place in the liver, where it is metabolised and excreted as urea (urea cycle). Due to impairment of ammonia metabolism in advanced liver disease, ammonia levels increase which withdraws α-ketoglutarate to form glutamate and glutamine.

 

 

This in turn results in lowered concentrations of citric acid cycle intermediates, and hence decreased ATP synthesis.

questions.text: What is the gold standard investigation for the diagnosis of myocarditis? (AIIMS NOV 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Endo-myocardial biopsy

 

An endo-myocardial biopsy is the gold standard investigation for the diagnosis of myocarditis.

 

Active myocarditis is characterized by an interstitial inflammatory infiltrate associated with degenerating or apoptotic myocytes.

 

Etiological classification of myocarditis:

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Magnetic Resonance Imaging: MRI can be used to detect myocardial inflammation and scarring, but it is not the gold standard. It is useful for non-invasive assessment but cannot definitively diagnose myocarditis without histological confirmation.

 

Option C. Brain Natriuretic Peptide (BNP): BNP is a biomarker used to assess heart failure but is not specific or sensitive for diagnosing myocarditis.

 

Option D. LDH1 to LDH2 ratio: This ratio is sometimes used in the context of myocardial infarction but does not have a role in diagnosing myocarditis.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Endo-myocardial biopsy remains the gold standard for diagnosing myocarditis, as it allows for direct histopathological examination of myocardial tissue.

 

Ref: Robbins pathologic basis of disease 8th edition pg 1064

questions.text: A 34-year-old male with Marfanoid habitus presents with sharp chest pain and sudden onset dyspnea. Chest X-ray was performed and is shown below. What is the most probable diagnosis? (INICET NOV 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. C Pneumothorax

 

Explanation:

 

The given CXR shows the presence of pneumothorax, which represents air in the pleural space. 

 

DIAGNOSIS: Right pneumothorax

 

MEDIASTINAL SHIFT: Contralateral

 

MOST SENSITIVE IX: CT scan

 

MOST SENSITIVE X-RAY: Expiratory X ray

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Pulmonary embolism: Often presents with sudden onset dyspnea and may show signs of right heart strain on imaging, but it does not directly cause the visible signs of air in the pleural cavity as seen in pneumothorax.

 

Option B. Hydropneumothorax: This would be indicated by both air and fluid levels within the pleural space, which are not visible in this X-ray.

 

Option D. Aortic dissection: Would potentially show mediastinal widening or other structural abnormalities, which are not depicted in this image.

 

Educational Objective:


Pneumothorax is identified by the visible presence of air in the pleural space, leading to lung collapse, and is commonly associated with sudden onset chest pain and dyspnea, especially in patients with connective tissue disorders like Marfan syndrome.

questions.text:
Identify the findings in freshwater drowning? (INICET Nov 2020)

  1. Hemodilution

  2. Hypokalemia

  3. Hyponatremia

  4. Arrhythmia
questions.solution:
Ans. D. 1, 3, 4

 

Rather than hypokalemia, there is an increase in potassium levels due to the release of intracellular potassium from swollen red blood cells. Hypokalemia is not typically a finding in freshwater drowning.

 

1. Haemodilution: Due to the excessive absorption of water through the alveolar-capillary membrane, the blood becomes diluted.

 

3. Hyponatremia: Haemodilution leads to a decrease in the concentration of sodium in the blood.

 

4. Arrhythmia: Electrolyte abnormalities caused by the haemodilution and resultant imbalance can lead to cardiac arrhythmias.

 

Educational Objective:

 

In cases of freshwater drowning, we see

 

  • Hemodilution – Due to excessive fluid absorption

  • Hyponatremia – Due to hemodilution

  • Arrythmia – Due to electrolyte abnormalities

  • Hyperkalemia -Due to release of intracellular potassium from swollen RBCs

choices.text: Type 1 Diabetes Mellitus association is high
Association with mucocutaneous candidiasis is high

questions.text: Which of the following is not typically associated with Autoimmune Polyendocrine Syndrome Type 1 (APS-1)? (INICET NOV 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Type 1 Diabetes Mellitus association is high

 

Type 1 Diabetes Mellitus does not have a high association with APS-1. The association is low and not a characteristic feature of APS-1.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Hypoparathyroidism is common: Hypoparathyroidism is common and is part of the classic triad of APS-1.

 

Option C. Association with mucocutaneous candidiasis is high: Mucocutaneous candidiasis is highly associated with APS-1. It is typically the first manifestation, appearing in infancy, and is also the most common manifestation due to underlying immunodeficiency.

 

Option D. Early onset in infancy: Early onset in infancy is characteristic of APS-1, with mucocutaneous candidiasis typically being the first manifestation to appear.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Classic triad of APS-1:

 

  1. Mucocutaneous candidiasis (most common and earliest manifestation)
  2. Hypoparathyroidism
  3. Addison's disease

questions.text: Which of the below agents cause hypertension when consumed?
questions.solution:
Ans. D. Cocaine

 

Cocaine is a stimulant (sympathomimetic) drug that typically leads to an increase in heart rate and blood pressure due to its effects on the cardiovascular system.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Organophosphorus: Organophosphorus compounds are cholinesterase inhibitors and cause cholinergic symptoms like bradycardia, hypotension, salivation, lacrimation, urination, defecation, gastrointestinal distress, and emesis (SLUDGE syndrome). They do not cause hypertension.

 

Option B. Phosphorus: Phosphorus poisoning typically leads to gastrointestinal symptoms (vomiting, diarrhea), jaundice, hepatic and renal failure. It does not cause hypertension.

 

Option C. Arsenic: Arsenic poisoning can cause a range of symptoms including gastrointestinal distress, peripheral neuropathy, skin changes (rain drop pigmentation), Mees' lines on nails, and long-term effects like cancer. It does not cause hypertension.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Cocaine is a sympathomimetic drug and has stimulant effects on CNS and cardiovascular system as mentioned below:

 

  • Agitation and Restlessness
  • Tachycardia / Palpitations
  • Hypertension
  • Dilated Pupils
  • Profuse Sweating
  • Hyperthermia
  • Restlessness
  • Paranoia and hallucinations.
  • Serious Cardiovascular Effects: Arrhythmias, Myocardial Infarction
  • Respiratory Distress: Rapid, shallow breathing and respiratory distress.
  • Seizures, Confusion and Altered Mental Status
